Armed assailants affiliated with the ""Islamic State"" (IS) attacked a compound owned by a cleaning company called Care Service in Al-Arish, North Sinai on 10 January. They set the compound on fire; however no injuries were reported among the company's workers. Eyewitnesses said the attackers evacuated all 125 employees from their dormitories before setting it ablaze, causing at least 40 vehicles owned by the authority to catch fire and a string of explosions in the area. One worker said he and other colleagues were not wounded, but revealed that the assailants, after checking the employees IDs, threatened them with death if they cooperate with security again.
Hundreds of participants gathered for the prayer and chanted denouncements of the government at the funeral of a doctor killed by policemen on 10 January in Fayoum.

There was an explosion on 12 January on Al-Ayatt railway track in the Giza Governorate. No causalities were reported in the blast. Two additional explosive devices were found on the railway track in front of Mansha Fadel in the town of Al-Ayatt. Explosives experts defused them.

The student union at Cairo University's Faculty of Arts said on 13 January they were staging a protest to denounce the death of a colleague, who died following a heart attack, after an observer kicked her out of her exam.
Defusal: A bomb disposal team defused an improvised explosive device planted near a school and a power transformer in Arish city.

North Sinai security forces killed 30 militants and injured 10 as militant elements attempted to attack a military ambush in south Sheikh Zuweid. The attack resulted in the death of four military personnel and the injury of eight others.
Two security recruits and a civilian were wounded on 14 January as a blast targeted a security patrol at the coastal road in the area between Arish and Sheikh Zuweid cities.
A primitive bomb exploded behind a closed traffic police unit on the Ring Road in Giza with no casualties reported.

A police officer, two conscripts and two civilians were injured on 19 January as a bomb went off near Al-Maydan checkpoint near North Sinais capital city Arish. A roadside bomb went off as a military vehicle was passing by. The Islamic State-affiliated State of Sinai group claimed responsibility on Twitter.

A young Egyptian man, was found dead on 31 January after having been reported missing for two weeks. He was arrested on 20 January from his house located in the Fifth Settlement suburb in Greater Cairo. His family were not informed of where he would be detained. Friends suspect that Galal was shot immediately after he went missing, and that his body may have been at the morgue for the entire ten days.

column16: AFP; Al Ahram; Egypt Independent; Xinhua
column17: Between five and seven Egyptian policemen were killed on 20 January in an armed attack in Egypts North Sinai city of Arish. Militants attacked security forces at Atlawy Square in Arish, killing five policemen and injuring 10 others. The Islamic State groups Egyptian affiliate, the Sinai Province, claimed that attack.

column16: AFP; Aswat Masriya (Egypt); Egypt Independent; Xinhua
column17: A bomb blast killed eleven people, including eight Egyptian policemen and three civilians, as a team of officers on 21 January raided an apartment in Al-Haram district suspected to be a militant hideout.The interior ministry blamed Thursdays incident on the blacklisted Islamist Muslim Brotherhood movement of ousted president Mohamed Morsi. However, Egypt Independent reported that both ISIS-affiliate group State of Sinai, and the Revolutionary Punishment groups claimed responsibility for the attack.

Police forces broke up three marches by Muslim Brotherhood supporters in the Berket al-Sabe, Tala and Ashmun localities, Monufiya on Friday. Protesters raised banners against President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi and others that read "" Where are bread and freedom?"", referring to the January 25 revolution slogan ""Bread, freedom and social justice"".

A missile killed one child and injured three people, after it hit their home in the Rafah city of Northern Sinai on Friday. Unknown assailiants ""fired a mortar shell at a security point in Rafah but it fell on the house by mistake.

Police forces broke up three marches by Muslim Brotherhood supporters in the Berket al-Sabe, Tala and Ashmun localities, Monufiya on Friday. Protesters raised banners against President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi and others that read "" Where are bread and freedom?"", referring to the January 25 revolution slogan ""Bread, freedom and social justice"".

Police forces broke up three marches by Muslim Brotherhood supporters in the Berket al-Sabe, Tala and Ashmun localities, Monufiya on Friday. Protesters raised banners against President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi and others that read "" Where are bread and freedom?"", referring to the January 25 revolution slogan ""Bread, freedom and social justice"".

Two policemen were wounded by gunfire when unknown elements opened fire at them in a village in Al-Sharqiyah Governorate [east of Cairo]. The two policemen were targeted by motorcyclists at Al-Qaramus village of Abu-Kabir city.
Defusal: Bomb disposal teams defused a high-explosive bomb that was planted by unidentified men under an armoured cash transport car in Wabur al-Miah district.

An attack on a checkpoint in a village in Egypts northern Sharqiya province left two policemen and a passerby dead on 24 January. The attack also left four people injured after unidentified assailants on two motorbikes shot at the checkpoint near the town of Fakous.

The Ministry of Interior said in a statement that it raided an apartment suspected to contain explosives in Kerdasa, and was caught in an ""exchange of fire"" with a member of the Muslim Brotherhood in the apartment, before shooting him.
Dozens of supporters of the Muslim Brotherhood blocked a main road in Bahtim, Qalyubiya on 25 January, burning car tires before fleeing away.
Anti-riot police forces dispersed a Muslim Brotherhood protest near Mataryia Square, with protestors reporting that police used live ammunition.
Supporters of the Muslim Brotherhood movement tried to demonstrate in Cairos Al-Haram district near the pyramids, but quickly dispersed fearing police retaliation.
Minor protests reportedly erupted in Bani Suaif and other provinces.

A protest was reported in 6 of October city, on the outskirts of Giza. Dozens demonstrated near Vodafone Square, denouncing the government and the police. They also raised posters of ousted Islamist president Mohamed Morsi. However, riot police dispersed the gathering within 30 minutes of its formation.

A number of protests were reported in Sharqeya, Fayoum, Menufiya and other governorates. Most demonstrations saw protesters lining residential streets or marching through populated neighborhoods. Some demonstrators set off fireworks before being dispersed by riot police.

A number of protests were reported in Sharqeya, Fayoum, Menufiya and other governorates. Most demonstrations saw protesters lining residential streets or marching through populated neighborhoods. Some demonstrators set off fireworks before being dispersed by riot police.

A number of protests were reported in Sharqeya, Fayoum, Menufiya and other governorates. Most demonstrations saw protesters lining residential streets or marching through populated neighborhood. Some demonstrators set off fireworks before being dispersed by riot police.
In Kafr El-Shiekh, eyewitnesses said police forces fired tear gas at protesters, after an attempt to block the international road in the city using burned tires.
In Shubra, three protesters were arrested after setting off fireworks and blocking roads.
Defusal: An improvised explosive device (IED) was defused in Alexandria Monday morning after civilians reported a suspicious object in Al-Max Street.

In Alexandria, police arrested 15 people when they dispersed small protests by Muslim Brotherhood loyalists. A total of four active demonstrations were reported in Alexandria, composed mostly of women. It was reported that the protesters carried antigovernment banners and posters depicting the the Rabaa Al-Adaweya sign.

A 32-year-old Egyptian government engineer disappeared in mid-January when, according to witnesses, masked police burst into his office in the southern city of Beni Suef and dragged him off in handcuffs in front of his co-workers. On Jan. 25, he turned up dead. Police provided a different story saying they shot and killed him when he tried to storm a checkpoint.

In the October 6 suburb of Cairo, police killed two suspected militants in a raid. Explosives and firearms were found in the raided apartment. The suspects opened fire at the security forces upon their arrival before the forces started to shoot back.

According to state news agency MENA, dozens of pro-government protesters marched through Tahrir Square and down Mohamed Mahmoud Street holding Egyptian flags and posters bearing the images of police victims, and chanting ""The police and the people are one hand"". Security forces and military tanks were close-at-hand.
A prisoner in the city of Sharqeya died in detention at Abu Hamad police station on 26 January, two days after his arrest, amid claims by his family that he was tortured.

One restaurant worker was mildly wounded when an IED exploded outside a court in Monufiya on 26 January. an IED planted opposite a district court in the city of Minuf caused the collapse of a primary school wall and two balconies from a nearby building. Four parked vehicles were destroyed as well.

Defusal: Security forces detonated two bombs planted near a main road west of Arish, North Sinai on 26 January. Eyewitnesses said the forces shot at the IEDs from a distance. The operation left no casualties.

An air raid reportedly killed 20 militants and wounded 15 others on 27 January at their hideouts near Arish International Airport while a massive militant cell was moving from southern Arish northwards to carry out activities.
Anti-government protesters in the village of Faqous, denounced the death of a prisoner in Abu Hamad police station, chanting against the police force.

The army shot and killed Attallah Abu Reteima, whom the sources identified as the person in charge of logistics for the Sinai Province group. The exchange of fire took place in a mountainous area in central Sinai.

A roadside bomb hit an armored personnel carrier south of Al-Arish in the Sinai Peninsula, killing an army colonel and four soldiers and wounding twelve others. IS affiliate the Sinai Province said its members used explosive devices to target the army west of El-Arish.

Fighting between army troops and militants in the northeastern part of the Sinai Peninsula killed four children and wounded eight other minors on 28 January. The Rafah hospital said in a statement that the children were killed and wounded during clashes using heavy weapons, with some buried under rubble when buildings were hit and collapsed. The fighting took place close to the border with the Palestinian Gaza Strip.
Police in Matariya hospital assaulted two doctors after they attempted to provide one of them with healthcare.

At least three policemen were killed and five others wounded on 28 January in a massive blast in a city in Egypts North Sinai province.The blast was caused by an improvised device targeting a police armored vehicle on a main road in downtown Al-Arish. State of Sinai later claimed responsibility.

A bomb blast killed two Egyptian police officers and wounded five others in an attack on their armoured vehicle in the Sinai Peninsula on 29 January. The vehicle was targeted near a school in the North Sinai provincial capital of El-Arish.

Dozens of Brotherhood loyalists took to the streets of Abu Hammad city of Sharqiya, 80 km north the Capital Cairo, to protest against the police. At least four people were injured by birdshots fired by Muslim Brotherhood protesters. Local shopkeepers were provoked and started confrontations, and the Brotherhood responded by firing birdshots.

Human Rights Monitor reported an extra-judicial violence case in which police forces arrested a man on 30 January while he was visiting his relative in Al-Aqrab prison. The group reported that Ibrahims family said their son did not return home after the visit.
A 17-year-old Coptic girl was kidnapped by two men riding a tuc-tuc on 31 January in the village of Hassan Basha in Samalout, Minya.
An army officer and a soldier were killed in a remotely-detonated bomb attack in the Sheikh Zuweyid region of northern Sinai on 31 January. There was no immediate claim of responsibility.
Two police conscripts were killed and two others injured after a roadside bomb exploded near an armoured police vehicle on 31 January in south Rafah in North Sinai.
Property destruction: Unidentified assailants set ablaze the houses of two police officers in Arish using Molotov cocktails on 31 January. There were no casualties since both houses were empty.

Thousands of supporters of Egyptian popular Al-Ahly Sporting Club, aka Ultras Ahlawy, gathered at the clubs stadium on 1 February to mark the fourth anniversary of the 2012 ""Port Said Massacre"" that left dozens dead. The Ultras (hard-core football fans), chanted slogans against the police, army and former army chief Field Marshal Muhammad Husayn Tantawi, saying: ""The people want to execute the field marshal.""
Three soldiers were injured in an IED blast in west Arish, North Sinai, on 1 February. The IED was planted by the perpetrators near the international road of Arish-Qantara Sharq at kilometer 17.

A government security guard was killed on 1 February in a drive-by shooting that targeted a traffic checkpoint on the Ring Road in Giza. The attackers purportedly mistook it for a security checkpoint. The employee killed was a security guard. Two assailants drove a motorcycle into the checkpoint and opened fire, killing the employee and injuring another with 14 bullets.

Eight militants were killed and two suspects were arrested in a joint crackdown by the armed forces and police in North Sinai on 2 February. The crackdown targeted areas in Arish, south Sheikh Zuweid and Rafah. 3 fatalities recorded in Rafah and 2 in Sheikh Zuweyid.

Eight militants were killed and two suspects were arrested in a joint crackdown by the armed forces and police in North Sinai on 2 February. The crackdown targeted areas in Arish, south Sheikh Zuweid and Rafah. 3 fatalities recorded in Al-Arish and 3 in Rafah.

A construction worker from Nahia, died on 7 February after sustaining injures when police forces attempted to arrest him on 2 February. He was injured by falling off the roof of his house during a police raid. His family suspects that the officers conducting the raid ""threw him off the roof"" and then sent him to the Boulaq Al-Dakrour hospital to avoid suspicion.

Eight militants were killed and two suspects were arrested in a joint crackdown by the armed forces and police in North Sinai on 2 February. The crackdown targeted areas in Arish, south Sheikh Zuweid and Rafah. 3 fatalities recorded in Al-Arish and 2 in Sheikh Zuweyid.
Some 500 villagers from Hassan Basha demonstrated on Wednesday 3 February in front of Minya governorate building demanding the return of a 17-year-old teenager kidnapped.

Pro-Qaddafi supporters protested at a seminar at the Cairo Book Fair addressed by Qaddafis former foreign minister and ambassador to the UN at the time of the revolution. The protesters threw bottles of water at him and accused him of bring a traitor.

Two members of the militant group Ajnad Misr (Soldiers of Egypt) were killed in a shootout with police forces in Cairo district of Hadiq al-Maadi on Wednesday [3 February]. Police raided the place, exchanged fire with the militants and seized large amount of weapons, ammunition and explosive materials.

A 28-year-old Italian Ph.D. student in Cambridge University, disappeared on Jan. 25. His deceased body was later found in a roadside ditch along a highway in the 6th of October suburb on Cairos western outskirts with stab wounds, cigarette burns and torture marks.

Taxi drivers organised a protest on 4 February near Mostafa Mahmoud mosque in Cairo, as they expressed their objections to private taxi services such as Uber and Careem, which have become popular among Egyptians recently.
19 were reportedly arrested on 4 and 5 February and were forcibly disappeared afterwards. They later reappeared in Al-Montazah Police station in Alexandria on 13 February.

Property destruction: Unidentified assailants used Molotov cocktails and fireworks to set fire to a police car on 4 February parked in a garage in Alexandrias Asafra neighborhood. Masked assailants on a motorcycle without number plates set fire to the car, affiliated with the polices traffic department.
19 were reportedly arrested on 4 and 5 February and were forcibly disappeared afterwards. They later reappeared in Al-Montazah Police station in Alexandria on 13 February.

Under a cover by the armed helicopters, army and police joint teams stormed a number of militant hotbeds in Al-Arish, Shaykh Zuwayid and Rafah in North Sinai, killing a total of 10 Islamist militants. 3 fatalities recorded in Rafah and 4 in Sheikh Zuweyid.

Under a cover by the armed helicopters, army and police joint teams stormed a number of militant hotbeds in Al-Arish, Shaykh Zuwayid and Rafah in North Sinai, killing a total of 10 Islamist militants. 3 fatalities recorded in Al-Arish and 4 in Sheikh Zuweyid.

Under a cover by the armed helicopters, army and police joint teams stormed a number of militant hotbeds in Al-Arish, Shaykh Zuwayid and Rafah in North Sinai, killing a total of 10 Islamist militants. 3 fatalities recorded in Rafah and 3 in Al-Arish.

Egyptian security forces arrested 10 young men from hard-core football fans, Ultras, following a protest they staged outside Al-Ahly club. The fans demonstrated to attend the training warmups of their team, but were not allowed inside. Police forces closed all roads leading to the club with metal barricades.
People demonstrated in front of Italian embassy in Cairo over the killed Italian student.

Three anonymous gunmen attacked Banha Teaching Hospitals gynaecology department on 6 February. One of the armed men purportedly claimed to be a police officer. Two of the doctors sustained concussions due to the attack, and the hospital was subsequently closed.
Four alleged militants affiliated with militant group Ajnad Misr were killed on 7 February during an exchange of fire with Egyptian police in a hideout in Al-Kurayimat village in Atfih township.

Members of Ultras White Knights gathered in the Fostat park in Cairo on 8 February and held a rally to commemorate the deaths of 22 people killed in clashes last year between the police and fans of the Zamalek football club. The fans set off firecrackers and waved banners as large numbers of security forces were deployed outside the park.

Two soldiers were injured on 9 February in an IED blast in southwest Sheikh Zuweid City, North Sinai. Unidentified assailants planted an IED in Karam al-Qawadis area, in southwest Sheikh Zuweid City. The bomb exploded as an armored vehicle passed near it while security forces were carrying out a crackdown in the area.

Three young men re-appeared in an Alexandria police station after police arrested them from their homes in an enforced disappearance. The men displayed signs of torture and their health had severely deteriorated. The exact date was not specified.
Three army conscripts were injured in an IED blast in Sheikh Zuweyid on 10 February. Unidentified assailants planted an IED in south Sheikh Zuweid City in North Sinai, targeting the security forces.
A bomb exploded on 11 February on the coastal road of North Sinai. Unidentified assailants planted a bomb in the Rawda area in Bir al-Abd locality on the Arish-Qantara Sharq Road.

""Sinai Province"" said that on 11 February it targeted a military camp and Al-Arish International Airport using BM21-Grad missiles, claiming they had executed this operation while both the interior minister and the defence minister were visiting the area.
On the North West coast in Masa Matrouh, a sit in was held by angry lawyers at the poor treatment by the police.
Thousands of Egyptian doctors staged a protest Friday outside their union headquarters in Cairo over a lack of legal action against policemen who allegedly beat up two of their colleagues.
According to Al-Watan, an Apache helicopter killed 45 Ansar Beit al-Maqdis (State of Sinai) militants and injured dozens. Location not specified.

One prisoner was killed and 17 others injured in an attempted prison break from the Hawamdya Giza police station on 13 February. Police forces tried to stop them by firing tear gas to prevent them from escaping. In the process, 17 people experienced suffocation and a prisoner died in hospital after sustaining ""bruises"" and ""fatigue"". The usage of tear gas was seen as evidence of using excessive violence against inmates.
One police conscript was shot dead by unknown assailants while he was on duty at a checkpoint in southern Al-Arish.

Two Egyptian soldiers, one an officer, were killed by an explosion as they tried to defuse a roadside bomb in in the area of Karm al-Qawadis, in Sheikh Zuweyid. The militant group Sinai Province also claimed the killing of seven security personnel during an incident inside the city of Al-Arish, however these claims could not be confirmed.
An officer and a conscript were killed, another conscript was injured while dismantling explosive device in Arish.

Families of Al-Aqrab prison inmates were attacked in front of the visiting hall on 14 February while they were waiting to visit their detained relatives. The incident started ""when a security officer assaulted a girl. The families then protested, which resulted in the officers banning most of their visits. The families then tried to enter, only to be beaten and assaulted by the officers and soldiers"".

The Egyptian army continued its operations on 15 February against militants in the area of Al-Arish in North Sinai. Tribal sources told Daily News Egypt that a reported five militants were killed as the army raided a den allegedly used by members of the militant group Sinai Province. The sources said the army used helicopters to execute the attack.

Human Rights Watch (HRW) released a report saying that six people arrested in the coastal city of Alexandria in February had reported to relatives that they were tortured with electric shocks and beatings. It said six of the detainees told relatives they were suspended by their arms, electrocuted in the genitals and punched. They had been arrested after an alleged arson attack on a police vehicle and a garage.

Four people were killed and three injured when clashes broke out between residents of the Bulaq Abul Ela area in downtown Cairo on 16 February. The incident began as an argument between two people over the guarding of a kiosk that belongs to the district.

Lawyers claimed that their colleague was attacked by a policeman in Basyoun in Gharbiya, sustaining cuts and bruises to his face. The altercation occurred when the policeman ordered the lawyer's relatives to park their tuk tuk away from the court's security deployment.
Dozens of lawyers protested outside the courtrooms complex in Basyoun, Gharbiya, on 16 February, condemning an alleged assault by a policeman on one of their colleagues.

Gunmen on a motorcycle opened fire on a checkpoint in Egypt on 16 February, killing a policeman and seriously wounding two others. The attack took place in an area called El-Badrasheen in southern Cairo. There were no immediate details about the assailants. An ISIS-affiliated group in Egypt claimed responsibility for the attack.
Dozens of students and professors participated in a demonstration to show solidarity with late Italian student Giulio Regeni at the American University in Cairo (AUC) on 17 February.

A civilian received a fatal bullet from a policeman who was trying to break up a melee that erupted near the Cairo police headquarters, a security official told MENA. The policeman used his gun and opened fire in the air to break up the brawl, but a civilian sustained a fatal injury.

Hundreds of protesters gathered outside of Cairos security directorate on 18 February after a police officer dressed in civilian clothes shot and killed a 24-year-old taxi driver. Disgruntled Egyptians beat up a policeman, blocked roads, and surrounded the local security headquarters after the officer killed a driver in a dispute.

A police officer dressed in civilian clothes shot and killed a 24-year-old taxi driver in el-Darb el-Ahmar district of Cairo. ""The policeman pulled out his gun to end the fight but a bullet came out by mistake, killing the taxi driver,"" the Interior Ministrys statement added.

On 18 February, tens of family members gathered in front of the Press Syndicate to protest the treatment of the prisoners in Al-Aqrab prison, demanding that the ministry allow winter clothing and visits.

The Egyptian branch of the Islamic State group posted pictures online of what it says was the execution of two men caught spying for the army in the Sinai. The images were deemed authentic by US monitor SITE Intelligence Group.

Hundreds of mourners turned out for the funeral of a taxi driver killed by a policeman on 19 February in Cairo. The protesters chanted against the police apparatus, and stood for a while in front of the Cairo Security Directorate.
Property destruction: A militant attack that targeted the main electricity line in Al-Shaykh Zuwayd and Rafah left both North Sinai cities, and nearby towns and villages, in a complete blackout.
Outraged residents of Al-darb Al-Ahmar protested against police violence.
Approximately 10-15 doctors protested in several hospitals, including Al-Matariya Teaching Hospital, condemning the violations and assaults against doctors on their jobs.
Doctors staged silent protests in front of Damietta General hospital in Egypt on 20 February 2016.

Dozens of family members gathered in front of the Press Syndicate in Cairo on 20 February to protest the treatment of their detained relatives, as well as demanding ""fair trials"" and ""an end to the death sentence"".
A police officer killed his neighbour on 20 February after a dispute escalated in Al-Khosoos.
Two Egyptian policemen were killed in a bomb explosion which targeted two vehicles in North Sinai. Specific location not detailed - coded to Al Arish.

Dozens of Niqab-wearing women from the Faculty of Medicine and Qasr Al-Aini hospitals staged a protest on 21 February outside the Qasr Al-Aini conference hall against Cairo University President Gaber Nassars decision to ban nurses and doctors from wearing the full-face veil in Qasr Al-Aini Medical School (QAMS) and its affiliated teaching hospitals.

Many low-ranking police officers in the Sharqeya governorate organised a protest on 21 February in front of the security directorate in Zagazig in solidarity with officers who were arrested after it was believed they were going to incite people against the Ministry of Interior. Protesters demanded their immediate release.

A student was killed and seven other civilians were injured when a bomb went off near Al-Arish, North Sinai, on Sunday [21 February]. State of Sinai claimed responsibility, saying it was targeting a police patrol in Bir Al Abd.

Masked security agents wearing civilian clothes and police uniforms raided a the home of a journalist in Damietta at dawn on 21 February, arrested the journalist, seized his laptop and his mobile phone, and took him away in a police vehicle. Four days after his arrest, he reported that he had been subject to torture by electric shock on four separate occasions and that security officers had pressured him to confess to crimes he did not commit.

A group of Nubian citizens and activists protested on 22 February at Aswans Abu Simbel Temple. The protest condemned a presidential decree, referred to as Decree 444, which designated a large stretch of land in Nubia as a new restricted military zone, adjacent to Egypts border with Sudan.
MP Mahmoud Khamis, an independent MP, assaulted a journalist in an attempt to prevent the media from interviewing MP Tawfik Okasha, after he was dismissed from parliament.
One person was killed and three others were severely injured after a missile fell on Rafah.
Defusal: Bomb squads in Giza dismantled two IEDs on al-Haram Street on 26 February, after the Civil Protection Agency received a tip from residents about two strange objects in front of a shop.
A police officer of the Badrasheen police station was killed on 26 February in a drive-by shooting in Giza by three unknown assailants.
A group of lawyers in Sharqeya claimed that a police conscript ""kidnapped"" their colleague in a case of enforced disappearance. The Ministry of Interior denied the claims.
A Muslim Brotherhood grouped planted a bomb exploding the main gas pipeline in Damietta governorate.

Security forces clashed with Islamist Muslim Brotherhood protesters in northern Egypt in a firefight, killing two of them and arresting six. The ministry said that the killed men were part of a group trying to stage a demonstration and carry out attacks against security forces in the northern city of Damietta. The Freedom and Justice Party, said in a statement that the men were killed protesting the military overthrow and price hikes. Two security men were injured.
Two conscripts were killed and two others injured in a roadside bomb explosion in Rafah in North Sinai.

Demolition: Security forces on Saturday [27 February] arrested a suspected man and destroyed a number of militant hotbeds in North Sinai. The crackdown targeted the areas of Al-Arish, southern Shaykh Zuwayid and Rafah. The forces also defused two explosive devices with no casualties reported.
A police captain was shot dead by masked gunmen outside his residence in Arish, North Sinai, on 27 February. State of Sinai claimed responsibility.

The Swiss-based organisation Alkarama reported two enforced disappearance case of two Egyptian students to the United Nations Working Group on Enforced or Involuntary Disappearances (WGEID). The second student was arrested from a pharmacy in the Fifth Settlement where he works, along with the pharmacys owner on 28 February.

Under the title ""Im Human"", some of Al-Aqrab (Tora) Prison detainees began a sit-in on 29 February inside the prison to protest the violations committed by the prison administration against the prisoners and their families

A prominent journalist and head of the Freedoms Committee at the Press Syndicat and a committee member held a sit-in on 29 February in an open strike at the syndicate to protest the poor conditions in prisons for detained journalists.
Passengers on a ferry that hit a fishing boat in Tahta, Sohag, Upper Egypt assaulted the captain, who was then taken to hospital.

An Egyptian man was beheaded and his teenage son shot dead in the Al-Arish in North Sinai on 29 February. No militant group has yet claimed responsibility for the attack. Activists claimed that the two men were assassinated by members of ""Sinai Province"", but this has not been confirmed.

The prime suspect in shooting of Head of the Shubra al-Khaymah Criminal Investigation Department Mustafa Lutfi was killed in a shootout with police in a district in Al-Qalyubiyah governorate on 16 March.

Three soldiers were killed on 2 March during an attack on an army patrol near Sinais Sheikh Zuweid. An IED ambush caught the patrol near Al-Wahshi checkpoint. At least one soldier was injured. The Sinai Province, the affiliate of the ""Islamic State"" (IS) in Egypt, claimed the attack.

Hundreds of Egyptian journalists organised a protest on 2 March in front of the Press Syndicate to demand the release of fellow detained journalists and protest the states tacit acceptance of their deteriorating health.

In Sinai on 2 March, a roadside bomb killed a conscript and wounded three soldiers when it struck a convoy of Humvees during a manhunt for a prominent militant leader. The attack was in the Khariza area near the town of Qasima. State of Sinai circulated reports which claimed the attack.

The administrator of a page on Facebook calling for a ""religious revolution"" was arrested on 3 March, after protesting at the headquarters of Al-Azhar. He called for the protest stating that Sahih Al-Bukharys Islamic teachings promote extremism and support ideologies of the Islamic State group. He burnt the book of Al-Bukharys teachings and the police forces arrested him.

Dozens of workers from the Nile Cotton Ginning Company staged a sit-in outside Itihadiya palace on 30 March demanding the payment of late salaries and after the administration decided to cancel scheduled bonuses.

The head of Shubra el Khayma criminal investigation department was killed during a security campaign to arrest a Khanka massacre suspect. The campaign took place in Jafra area in the Al-Qalubiyah central region of Shibin al-Qanatir.

A car bomb exploded on 4 March night in front of a building in the Mohandessin neighbourhood of Giza, leaving no casualties. The source said an explosion sound was heard on Gaza Street - where the Omani cultural mission headquarters lies.

Military operations were carried out by police forces and Egyptian armed forces in Sinai on 4 March. Security authorities indicated that 4 ""Sinai Province"" militants were killed and 6 injured in the Karam El-Qawdis region situated of Sheikh Zuweid.
A police officer was reportedly killed on 4 March after being injured in clashes with militants in the city of Rafah.

Five bullet-riddled bodies were found in a mass grave some hundreds of metres away from a well-known army base in Sheikh Zuweyid. State-controlled Cairo press simply said five unidentified bodies found killed. But local journalists reported that ""a hummer disposed of the bodies in plain sight, and among the murdered were a child and a deaf and mute victim"".

column9: Military Forces of Egypt (2014-); Health Workers (Egypt)
column17: On 6 March, after a blast wounded two Egyptian security personnel, gunmen shot dead two members of Egypts security forces in an ambulance after they had been injured by a bombing in the Sinai Peninsula. A medic in the ambulance was also killed in the ambush in the town of Sheikh Zuweyid. No militant group has yet claimed responsibility for either the bomb attack or the subsequent ambush.
A blast targeted the armoured vehicle of Egypts security forces in the town of Sheikh Zuweyid in North Sinai. Two security personnel were wounded.
Second Field Army troops prepared a checkpoint in Al-Sabkha district in Al-Shaykh Zuwayid, northern Sinai when militants opened fire. The troops repelled the attack killing five elements.
A lawyer was allegedly arrested and kidnapped on 7 March by police forces from his house in Gharbeya. His family said his whereabouts is still unknown and they do not know of what he is accused.

A roadside bombing in Egypts Sinai Peninsula killed two policemen on 7 March. The bomb exploded close to an armoured vehicle on a highway near El-Arish. ""Sinai Province"" claimed responsibility for the IED explosion. Other sources reported five killed - 2 fatalities recorded.

A soldier in the Egyptian armed forces was killed when an improvised explosive device (IED) detonated near an armoured police vehicle that was on patrol in the El-Mahdia region in Rafah in the North Sinai governorate. The planted IED was activated remotely by a member of the ""Sinai Province"" militant group.
Female relatives of women prisoners chanted at an event called Release Our Girls during International Womens Day in front of the Press Syndicate in Cairo, Egypt on 8 March.

A total of 3 soldiers were reported killed in North Sinai on 8 March in two explosions in Egypts North Sinai governorate. The exact location was not specified. 2 fatalities recorded (1 other fatality recorded in Al Mahdiyah).

Egyptian security forces fired tear gas on 8 March to disperse taxi drivers who had blocked a major road in the capital, Cairo, to protest Uber and other car-hailing applications, which the head of the Cairo traffic police insists are illegal. The drivers blocked Mustafa Mahmud Square, in Mohandiseen district, causing traffic congestion.
Two Egyptian soldiers were killed when an explosive device went off at a gas station south of Al-Shaykh Zuwayid, in northern Sinai on 9 March.
Three civilians were injured when an explosive device, which was placed in a street in the Feisal neighborhood, was detonated on 9 March while a police convoy was passing through.

A group of lawyers protested outside the Lawyers Syndicate, demanding security officials reveal the whereabouts of a detained lawyer. The syndicates Freedoms Committee refused to participate in the protest.
Hundreds demonstrated on 9 March in front of the Press Syndicate to demand the release of their fellow journalists and improvement of the poor conditions inside prisons.

A civilian was shot dead by police forces in Haram district in Giza, after he was chased by security members. The Shehab Centre for Human Rights said it was an act of extra-judicial killing. It held the Ministry of Interior responsible for the killing, calling upon the prosecution to investigate the case.

Hundreds of sanitation workers employed by the Nahdat Misr Company in Alexandria started a strike on 10 March. The striking workers allege that they have not received their salaries for the month of February and have only received half of their due pay for January. The workers protested inside the headquarters of the company demanding the payment of late salaries, accusing the management of ""avoiding"" the workers and of ""blaming the monetary problems on the governorate"". The strike ended on 14 March.

State-security forces killed 12 militants on 11 March during airstrikes against ""Islamic State""-affiliated groups in North Sinai. Apache helicopters were used to target several facilities of IS-affiliated militants; aiming to eliminate ammunition stores and vehicles, according to testimonies from residents on social media. in the same campaign, a police officer was reportedly killed on by an IED during a patrol in Sheikh Zuweid city in North Sinai.

Since 10 March, sanitation workers at Nahdat Misr Company protested inside company headquarters, demanding the payment of overdue wages and accusing management of avoiding workers and of ""blaming the monetary problems on the governorate"".

Dozens of doctors gathered in front of the Doctors Syndicate headquarters in downtown Cairo on 12 March to protest against repeated assaults, most of which have recently been carried out by police officers inside hospitals.

Since 10 March, sanitation workers at Nahdat Misr Company protested inside company headquarters, demanding the payment of overdue wages and accusing management of avoiding workers and of ""blaming the monetary problems on the governorate"".

Security forces stated that an IED was detonated near a military convoy south of Sheikh Zuweid city, located in North Sinai. No injuries were reported and state security forces set up a checkpoint in an attempt to arrest those responsible for the incident. The State of Sinai claimed responsibility.
Reports circulated on social media claimed that three citizens were injured by an IED that exploded as a car passed over it on a road south of Rafah city.

Since 10 March, sanitation workers at Nahdat Misr Company protested inside company headquarters, demanding the payment of overdue wages and accusing management of avoiding workers and of ""blaming the monetary problems on the governorate"".
Defusal: Social media reports said that police forces in Al-Arish were able to dismantle a bomb planted near Al-Nasr Mosque, after receiving a notification that it was found beside a parked car.
An Egyptian police officer was shot dead by masked individuals in North Sinai on 14 March near al-Arish police station.

State of Sinai militant group published photos allegedly showing the official uniforms, laptops and explosive detection devices of the Egyptian armed forces. The photos were provided as documentation of a raid on an armed forces checkpoint in Central Sinai on 14 March. Exact location not specified.

Since 10 March, sanitation workers at Nahdat Misr Company protested inside company headquarters, demanding the payment of overdue wages and accusing management of avoiding workers and of ""blaming the monetary problems on the governorate"".
During the month of March 2016, Military Air Forces destroyed several houses in airstrikes on Al Arish.

A police officer was killed and four CSF recruits were injured on 16 March in an IED blast in Sheikh Zuweyid city, North Sinai. Unidentified assailants planted an IED in the path of a security force vehicle in the area of Mahdeya, south Sheikh Zuweyid.

Egyptian military forces in Northern Sinais Rafah killed three ""militants"" during an ""exchange of fire"" on 17 March. Whilst raiding and combing militant hideouts they spotted three Islamist militants who had been trying to plant an explosive device in Rafah.
An explosive device killed an army soldier in the town of Sheikh Zuweyid. The Egypt Independent reported that the security member was a police conscript.

In Rafah, militants struck a weapons depot, killing at least five soldiers and injuring 10 others. Officials said that the attacks took place when suspected militants launched mortar shells at an army camp in Rafah.
The Doctors Syndicate continued their protest in front of public hospitals on 19 March, demanding that the accused police officers be referred to trial.

A mortar attack on an Al-Arish checkpoint in Egypts Sinai Peninsula killed 15 policemen on 19 March. The Islamic State group (IS) claimed responsibility for the attack, but said in a statement that it had deployed a suicide bomber who blew up a car at the checkpoint, which the militants then raided. Security officials said five attackers were killed in clashes near the checkpoint after the attack.

Egyptian security forces killed 10 members of the Sinai Province militant group in the North Sinai town of Sheikh Zuweyid. The deaths occurred during a raid by security forces on a militant camp in the south of the town, following a tip-off that a large number of Sinai Province militants - who are affiliated to the Islamic State group - were gathering ahead of a planned operation.

Dozens of government employees gathered in front of the Press Syndicate on 20 March in objection to an attempt to repass the civil service bill, amid tight security. Demonstrators called on the cabinet to resign. Instead of the controversial civil service bill, they called for the preparation of a uniform law for all state employees without exception to be put forward for public discussion.

Hundreds of small-scale importers demonstrated on 22 March in front of the Egyptian International Trade Point (EITP) at the Finance Ministry building in protest against decisions No. 991, 992, and 43, taken by Minister of Industry and Foreign Trade Tarek Qabil, which restrict imports.
Mothers of forcefully disappeared individuals staged a demonstration on 23 March. Location not specified.

Egyptian police announced they had killed a gang of five Egyptian men they said specialized in kidnapping and robbing foreigners. The interior ministry announced that the gang was tied to the killing of an Italian PhD student. However, counter reports suggest the men were unarmed and tried to flee as police fired on them, and that afterward police confiscated footage from security cameras near the scene. The men's relatives say they were house painters merely heading to a job in the Fifth Settlement suburb.

The Egyptian army killed 60 militants and injured 40 more in North Sinai on 25 March south of Rafah and Sheikh Zuweyid in North Sinai. The toll could not be independently verified. 30 fatalities reported in Sheikh Zuweyid.

The Egyptian army killed 60 militants and injured 40 more in North Sinai on 25 March south of Rafah and Sheikh Zuweyid in North Sinai. The toll could not be independently verified. 30 fatalities reported in Rafah.
The Egyptian army killed 19 militants south of Sheikh Zuweid city in the North Sinai province on 26 March.
Four police personnel were reportedly injured on 26 March by an improvised explosive device (IED) that detonated ahead of their armoured tank in the city of Al-Arish.
Defusal: Bomb-experts in Al-Arish succeeded in dismantling an explosive device on 26 March, which was found on the road near Palm Plaza.

""Sinai Province"" claims it killed a total of 15 state-security soldiers by planting explosive devices on roads situated in Sheikh Zuweid and Rafah. Aamaq, a news agency affiliated with Islamic State claimed that ""Sinai Province"" militants intercepted a counter-attack by the Egyptian Armed Forces and captured two tanks. 8 fatalities recorded in Sheikh Zuweid, 7 fatalities recorded in Rafah.

""Sinai Province"" claims it killed a total of 15 state-security soldiers by planting explosive devices on roads situated in Sheikh Zuweid and Rafah. Aamaq, a news agency affiliated with Islamic State claimed that ""Sinai Province"" militants intercepted a counter-attack by the Egyptian Armed Forces and captured two tanks. 8 fatalities recorded in Sheikh Zuweid, 7 fatalities recorded in Rafah.

On 28 March, a pregnant Bedouin woman was alleged to have been subjected to shooting from army forces inside the El-Tarabin district in Sheikk Zuwaid. The shooting resulted in injuring her with two bullets in her arm and belly, killing the foetus, according eyewitnesses testimonies to the EORF.

Three suspected militants were killed in army raid following an exchange of fire near Sinais Sheikh Zuweid on 30 March. A force of the second field army was setting up a checkpoint when it became suspicious of three men riding motorcycles without plates. According to an army statement, the suspects opened fire on the personnel when the force tried to stop them for inspection, which led to the killing of the three suspects.
A suspected militant was killed on 30 March in a shootout in Gizas Warraq neighbourhood after an exchange of fire with a police force.

The Egyptian army killed 65 militants in North Sinai, it was reported on 1 April. This came as the army, in cooperation with police, targeted a number of arms caches in Rafah and Sheikh Zuweid. 33 fatalities recorded in Sheikh Zuweyid and 32 fatalities recorded in Rafah.

The Egyptian army killed 65 militants in North Sinai, it was reported on 1 April. This came as the army, in cooperation with police, targeted a number of arms caches in Rafah and Sheikh Zuweid. 33 fatalities recorded in Sheikh Zuweyid and 32 fatalities recorded in Rafah.

A police conscript and a citizen were reportedly killed on 1 April and another soldier was wounded when an explosive detonated targeting a police patrol crossing the coastal road in Al-Arish, North Sinai governorate.
Dozens of workers in the Nile Cotton Ginning Company went on an open strike on 3 April inside the company's headquarters in Mahalla, demanding the payment of late salaries.

Dozens of temporary workers within the Agriculture Ministrys Land Reclamation Sector protested on 4 April outside ministry headquarters in Dokki neighborhood, demanding permanent contracts and full financial rights for 323 employees.

A police sergeant was killed in an attack by masked gunmen at Khosous checkpoint, Qaliubiya, on 4 April. A captain and a police secret informant also sustained injuries when the assailants opened fire from two cars, using automatic rifles.

A total of two militants were killed in central Sinai by the Egyptian army on 6 April. One militants was killed in Wady Gerba after hurling a hand grenade against a patrol while the other was killed in Khreza area in a shootout.

A total of two militants were killed in central Sinai by the Egyptian army on 6 April. One militants was killed in Wady Gerba after hurling a hand grenade against a patrol while the other was killed in Khreza area in a shootout.

The assistant director of the North Sinai security directorate was injured on 6 March in an explosion on al-Arish-Qantara road. A roadside bomb went off as security forces were on patrol to secure a cash transport vehicle.

Two armored personnel carriers were hit by remotely-detonated explosions in North Sinai: one in Kharouba village south Sheikh Zuwaid city, and the other happened 500 meters away from Rafah police station on 7 April. At least four soldiers and one officer were killed and 11 others injured in the two explosions. The Islamic State (IS) group claimed responsibility for the attacks on its twitter official page, but the statement said 18 soldiers were killed in series of attacks near Sheikh Zuwaid and Rafah cities.

Two armored personnel carriers were hit by remotely-detonated explosions in North Sinai: one in Kharouba village south Sheikh Zuwaid city, and the other happened 500 meters away from Rafah police station on 7 April. At least four soldiers and one officer were killed and 11 others injured in the two explosions. The Islamic State (IS) group claimed responsibility for the attacks on its twitter official page, but the statement said 18 soldiers were killed in series of attacks near Sheikh Zuwaid and Rafah cities.

Two police officers and two conscripts from North Sinais security forces were killed in an exchange of gun fire in central Sinai on 8 April. Security forces manning a checkpoint in the Qasima area were fired upon by unidentified attackers, with four conscripts killed in the resulting exchange of fire. One of the militants was reportedly killed during the attack.

Security forces arrested on 10 April two men demonstrating in Al-Saa square in Damanhour. They were protesting against the cabinet decision placing Sanafir and Tiran islands under the sovereignty of Saudi Arabia.
Families of imprisoned journalists began an open ended sit-in at the Press Syndicate headquarters on 10 April.

Five people were arrested on 10 April for protesting in Talaat Harb Square in downtown Cairo against a maritime border demarcation agreement in which Egypt stipulated that two Red Sea islands, Tiran and Sanafir, fall within Saudi territorial waters. Critics said that President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi has ""sold Egypt"" to the Saudi king in return for Saudi aid.
Two Egyptian soldiers were killed and others injured as their vehicle was attacked in North Sinai on 11 April. No further details were provided.

On 14 April, security forces dispersed two protests in the vicinity of Al-Istiqama mosque in Giza and Mostafa Mahmoud mosque in Mohandiseen district, using tear gas. Several protesters were arrested. The protests were over the signing of a maritime border demarcation agreement that locates the two islands of Tiran and Sanafir within Saudi territorial waters.

On 14 April, security forces dispersed two protests in the vicinity of Al-Istiqama mosque in Giza and Mostafa Mahmoud mosque in Mohandiseen district, using tear gas. Several protesters were arrested. The protests were over the signing of a maritime border demarcation agreement that locates the two islands of Tiran and Sanafir within Saudi territorial waters. A journalist for the daily newspaper Al-Watan, and a photographer for the daily newspaper Al-Fagr, were shot by rubber-coated bullets while covering the protest moving from the Istiqama Mosque in Giza across the river to central Cairos Tahrir Square.

Fans in April forced their way into a stadium in protest against the ban on supporters attending football matches. At the Borg Al-Arab stadium in Alexandria, Ultras Ahlawy stormed the pitch during an African Championship match against the backdrop of growing criticism of general-turned-president Abdel Fattah Al-Sisi, and protests against his handing over of two islands in the Red Sea to Saudi Arabia during a visit to Cairo in May by Saudi King Salman bin Abdulaziz Al-Saud.

Protests against the handing over of the islands of Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi control, part of the recent agreement on maritime borders between Egypt and Saudi Arabia, were reported in the governorates of Mansoura, Sharqeya, Hurghada, and Sohag as well as 9 other governorates.
Protests were reported in the governorates of Ismailia, Aswan and Luxor against the decision to hand over of the islands of Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi control.

Protests against the handing over of the islands of Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi control, part of the recent agreement on maritime borders between Egypt and Saudi Arabia, were reported in the governorates of Mansoura, Sharqeya, Hurghada, and Sohag as well as 9 other governorates.
Protests were reported in the governorates of Ismailia, Aswan and Luxor against the decision to hand over of the islands of Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi control.
Protests were reported in the governorates of Ismailia, Aswan and Luxor against the decision to hand over of the islands of Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi control.

Protests against the handing over of the islands of Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi control, part of the recent agreement on maritime borders between Egypt and Saudi Arabia, were reported in the governorates of Mansoura, Sharqeya, Hurghada, and Sohag as well as 9 other governorates.

Protests against the handing over of the islands of Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi control, part of the recent agreement on maritime borders between Egypt and Saudi Arabia, were reported in the governorates of Mansoura, Sharqeya, Hurghada, and Sohag as well as 9 other governorates.

According to the Socialist Popular Alliance Party, around 12 protesters were arrested in the Ibrahimia district of Alexandria after demonstrations against the handing over of the islands of Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi control, part of the recent agreement on maritime borders between Egypt and Saudi Arabia.

25 protesters were arrested in the city of Alexandria on 15 April, after demonstrating against the handing over of the islands of Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi control, part of the recent agreement on maritime borders between Egypt and Saudi Arabia.

Security forces dispersed protests in the areas of Montazah, Second Raml, Mina al-Basal, and Bab Sharqy, chasing protesters down side streets. The protesters were demonstrating against the handing over of the islands of Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi control, part of the recent agreement on maritime borders between Egypt and Saudi Arabia.

Security forces dispersed protests in the areas of Montazah, Second Raml, Mina al-Basal, and Bab Sharqy, chasing protesters down side streets. The protesters were demonstrating against the handing over of the islands of Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi control, part of the recent agreement on maritime borders between Egypt and Saudi Arabia.

Demonstrations in Sayida Zeinb and Ain Shams converged at the Press Syndicate, the Socialist Popular Alliance told Daily News Egypt. In Ain Shams, security forces and civilians working with the police arrested nine protesters. Demonstrations were against the handing over of the islands of Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi control, part of the recent agreement on maritime borders between Egypt and Saudi Arabia.

Demonstrations in Sayida Zeinb and Ain Shams converged at the Press Syndicate, the Socialist Popular Alliance told Daily News Egypt. In Ain Shams, security forces and civilians working with the police arrested nine protesters. Demonstrations were against the handing over of the islands of Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi control, part of the recent agreement on maritime borders between Egypt and Saudi Arabia.

Security forces dispersed protests in the areas of Montazah, Second Raml, Mina al-Basal, and Bab Sharqy, chasing protesters down side streets. The protesters were demonstrating against the handing over of the islands of Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi control, part of the recent agreement on maritime borders between Egypt and Saudi Arabia.

Security forces dispersed protests in the areas of Montazah, Second Raml, Mina al-Basal, and Bab Sharqy, chasing protesters down side streets. The protesters were demonstrating against the handing over of the islands of Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi control, part of the recent agreement on maritime borders between Egypt and Saudi Arabia.

Thousands of protesters demonstrated on 15 April outside the Journalists Syndicate, located in downtown Cairo. Security troops attempted to disperse the protesters using teargas and chased them down side streets. More than 100 people arrested.

According to the civil society organisation Freedom for the Brave, police officers assaulted detainees, who were arrested during protests on 15 April, in Tora prison and forced them to undress and remain naked. The officers also cut the electricity to prisoners cells and only gave them one blanket.

Two soldiers were reportedly injured and three militants killed on 16 April in an attack that targeted the Armed Forces El Masora checkpoint near the entrance to Rafah city in North Sinai. The attack was foiled. An armoured also tank exploded due to the detonation of an improvised explosive device (IED). The tank was stationed at the entrance of Al-Arish city and resulted in a number of soldier injuries.

Students staged a protest on Tanta Universitys campus on 16 April. A student-led campaign dubbed ""Students will not sell"" was launched in the wake of the nationwide movement condemning the recent Egyptian-Saudi maritime demarcation deal.

Students at several campuses, including Cairo University, Helwan University, and others, organised protests against the decision to hand over of the islands of Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi control. According to the organiser, security officers continued to chase them even after they left.

Students at several campuses, including Cairo University, Helwan University, and others, organised protests against the decision to hand over of the islands of Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi control. At Helwan University a group of students were briefly detained at the deans office after organising on-campus protests.

The families of inmates in Tantas first district police station protested while security forces were dealing with a riot situation inside the police station. The families, believing that a fire had broken out, gathered in front of the police station.

column6: Police Forces of Egypt (2014-) Prison Guards
column17: On 18 April, several detainees held at Tantas first district police station in Gharbeya governorate set light to clothes and blankets inside their detention cells. Officials immediately moved to the police station to end it. Guards sprayed water from fire hoses to disperse the inmates who were quarrelling. This action resulted in five inmates being slightly wounded.

column16: Al Ahram; Egypt Independent; Tahrir News (Egypt)
column17: Two citizens were reported killed while three conscripts and eight other civilians were injured in an explosion in Al Arish in Egypts North Sinai. The bomb was targeting a prisoner transport van. Wilyat Sinai claimed the IED attack.
On April 18, in the morning, at Maasara checkpoint, close to Al Arish, policemen shot at a truck and killed one man.

Scores of Cairo residents protested on 19 April after an Egyptian police officer shot and killed a street vendor and wounded two others. Bystanders protested at the scene of the shooting, chanting: ""The police are thugs"", smashing a police car and an ambulance and beating up another police officer as they blocked a road in the aftermath of the shooting. Riot squads were deployed to disperse the crowd.

A non-commissioned officer was killed in Minya governorate while chasing three gunmen on 19 April. A group of police personnel tried to stop two motorcycles while they were patrolling a road leading to Abaza village, leading to an exchange of fire.

The families of detained protesters were assaulted while waiting outside a Cairo court for a verdict on 19 April. As security forces escorted the detainees to the prisoner transport vehicle among a crowd of relatives and activists, a group of women - likely to have been commissioned by an unconfirmed party - attacked all women and girls present, particularly targeting young photojournalists. The police did not intervene to stop the assaults.
At least three police conscripts were killed and eight others injured on 19 April as Sinai Province militants targeted their convoy with an RPG in Sheikh Zeweid city in North Sinai province.

Several social media users claimed on 20 April that civilians were killed in Sheikh Zuweid due to random shelling from an unknown source. A child was killed and seven others injured in the Al-Tarabin suburb of Sheikh Zuweid. The shelling is believed to be a mistake on the part of the army during clashes with militants,"" a North Sinai-based journalist told Daily News Egypt.

Three students in Assiut University were arrested on 20 April following a protest over the sovereignty transfer of the Tiran and Sanafir islands. The students, who belong to the Bread and Freedom Party, the Egyptian Social Democratic Party, and the 6 April Youth Movement, were taken from the university campus to a police station.
A group of students from Ain Shams University were briefly detained, on 20 April, following a protest over the sovereignty transfer of the Tiran and Sanafir islands.

Arrests: Security forces arrested between 40 - 79 people on the evening of 20 April during a series of raids on downtown Cairos cafes in an attempt to thwart anti-state protests scheduled for 25 April. Egyptian security forces rounded up dozens of activists, journalists, and lawyers ahead of demonstrations called for April 25 against President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissis policies, including the transfer of two Red Sea islands to Saudi Arabia. Police forces were wearing plainclothes whilst arresting people, the initiative reported. The counted arrests for the night were as following: 26 people from ""Ghazal"" cafe, 10 from ""El-Fallah"" cafe, six from a cafe in Korba, Heliopolis, four in Alexandria, two in Gharbeya. A prominent leftist activist and member of the Revolutionary Socialists movement was among the activists who were arrested from their homes.

Two conscripts and one officer were injured on 22 April after a bomb exploded in Northern Sinais Arish. Anonymous people planted a bomb on one of Arishs main roads, which led to the explosion of a police car and the injury of three men. Another four conscripts were reported injured in a similar explosion in Al-Arish in North Sinai.
Unconfirmed reports mentioned heavy clashes between army forces and militants in Shiekh Zuwied on 22 April.
Eight lawyers received arrest warrants for protesting without a permit in front of the Lawyers Syndicate on 23 April.

Pro-Sisi demonstrations took place in Mohandessin and central Cairo at which Saudi flags were waved enthusiastically. Giant speakers mounted on pick-up trucks drove around downtown Cairo blasting out the pro-military song Teslam Al-Ayadi (blessed are the hands).

On 25 April, flash protests were reported in in Mahalla. Protesters voiced anti-government chants, demanded the removal of President Abdel-Fattah Al-Sisi and denounced the agreement under which Egypt ceded two Red Sea islands to Saudi Arabia earlier this month. Three members of political parties were arrested.

Egypts security forces dispersed six protests in Cairo and Giza held in opposition to the sovereign transfer of the two Red Sea islands Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi Arabia. Dozens of protesters marched from Nahia street in the Giza district of Boulaq Al-Dakrour amid tight security measures adopted ahead of planned protests. Security forces dispersed the protest in Nahia using birdshots and arrested seven protesters.

On 25 April, flash protests were reported in Faisal. In the short time before protestors were dispersed by police they voiced anti-government chants, demanded the removal of President Abdel-Fattah Al-Sisi and denounced the agreement under which Egypt ceded two Red Sea islands to Saudi Arabia earlier this month.
Protesters in Fayoum denounced the agreement under which Egypt ceded two Red Sea islands to Saudi Arabia earlier this month. The protest ended before security forces arrived.

The Freedom and Justice Party, the political arm of the outlawed Muslim Brotherhood, reported on 25 April, the beginning of several protests in the governorates of Sharqeya, Daqahliya, and Kafr El-Sheikh. The protests in Sharqeya and Daqahliya were reportedly met with a strict security clampdown.

The Freedom and Justice Party, the political arm of the outlawed Muslim Brotherhood, reported on 25 April, the beginning of several protests in the governorates of Sharqeya, Daqahliya, and Kafr El-Sheikh. The protests in Sharqeya and Daqahliya were reportedly met with a strict security clampdown.

Several demonstrations broke out on Monday in Alexandria, Ismailiya, Damietta, Menufiya, and Sohag, which were met with a strict security clampdown. Protesters mobilised in opposition to the sovereign transfer of the two Red Sea islands Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi Arabia.

Several planned demonstrations broke out on 25 April including in Aswan and Luxor, which were met with a strict security clampdown. Protesters mobilised in opposition to the sovereign transfer of the two Red Sea islands Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi Arabia.

Two small marches went to the streets of Beni Suef governorate. Despite harassment from security forces, the protestors continued their demonstrations. Protesters mobilised in opposition to the sovereign transfer of the two Red Sea islands Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi Arabia.

Several demonstrations broke out on Monday in Alexandria, Ismailiya, Damietta, Menufiya, and Sohag, which were met with a strict security clampdown. Protesters mobilised in opposition to the sovereign transfer of the two Red Sea islands Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi Arabia.

Several demonstrations broke out on Monday in Alexandria, Ismailiya, Damietta, Menufiya, and Sohag, which were met with a strict security clampdown. Protesters mobilised in opposition to the sovereign transfer of the two Red Sea islands Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi Arabia.

Several planned demonstrations broke out on 25 April including in Aswan and Luxor, which were met with a strict security clampdown. Protesters mobilised in opposition to the sovereign transfer of the two Red Sea islands Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi Arabia.
On 25 April, protests were dispersed including those in Nahya in Giza. Protesters mobilised in opposition to the sovereign transfer of the two Red Sea islands Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi Arabia.

Several demonstrations broke out on Monday in Alexandria, Ismailiya, Damietta, Menufiya, and Sohag, which were met with a strict security clampdown. Protesters mobilised in opposition to the sovereign transfer of the two Red Sea islands Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi Arabia.

Several demonstrations broke out on Monday in Alexandria, Ismailiya, Damietta, Menufiya, and Sohag, which were met with a strict security clampdown. Protesters mobilised in opposition to the sovereign transfer of the two Red Sea islands Tiran and Sanafir to Saudi Arabia.

The Freedom and Justice Party, the political arm of the outlawed Muslim Brotherhood, reported on 25 April, the beginning of several protests in the governorates of Sharqeya, Daqahliya, and Kafr El-Sheikh. The protests in Sharqeya and Daqahliya were reportedly met with a strict security clampdown.

The Egyptian army killed 30 alleged militants in North Sinai in a ""successful pre-emptive air strike"". The forces have also damaged weapons and explosives warehouses in Al-Sheikh Zuweid and Al-Toma towns. Daily News Egypt reported the militants to be from Sinai Province.

In Cairo, dozens of supporters gathered outside Maadi Hospital to salute ousted President Mubarak for his role in the liberation of Sinai when he was in office. The supporters carried placards celebrating the ex-president and shouted pro-Mubarak chants.

On 25 April, security forces detained at least 17 journalists in downtown Cairo, while others were assaulted, when military and police conducted sweeps to detain potential demonstrators and to close streets leading to the site of a planned protest at the Journalists Syndicate. The street protests demonstrated against a deal handing control of two Red Sea Islands to Saudi Arabia.

On 25 April, flash protests were reported in eastern Cairo's Nasr City. In the short time before protestors were dispersed by police they voiced anti-government chants, demanded the removal of President Abdel-Fattah Al-Sisi and denounced the agreement under which Egypt ceded two Red Sea islands to Saudi Arabia earlier this month.

The headquarters of the Nasserist Al-Karama party, which is part of the campaign protesting the maritime demarcation agreement that will transfer the sovereignty of Tiran and Sanafir islands to Saudi Arabia, was surrounded by security forces for more than four hours as protesters were locked in following a protest in Gizas Dokki. In the residential square in Dokki, 500 protesters led by prominent activists gathered. Chants of ""leave, leave"" directed at el-Sissi, echoed across the square, along with ""bread, freedom, the islands are Egyptian."" Masked policemen atop armored vehicles and in full riot gear arrived 10 minutes later and immediately fired tear gas and birdshot. At least 100 protesters were arrested, mostly in the Dokki district in Cairos twin city of Giza. At least 16 journalists were detained while covering protests.

On 25 April, flash protests were reported in in Cairos Talaat Harb Street. 270 people were reported arrested. Before protestors were dispersed by police, they voiced anti-government chants, demanded the removal of President Abdel-Fattah Al-Sisi and denounced the agreement under which Egypt ceded two Red Sea islands to Saudi Arabia earlier this month. The protesters who gathered in a small square came under tear gas fire after a first police van at the scene was pelted with stones. Supporters of President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi were also seen chanting ""the police and the people and the army are one hand"". Around 50 activists, including leading leftist dissidents, gathered suddenly at a city centre square. Rocks were thrown at police who responded with tear gas.

On 26 April, some two dozen journalists gathered outside the Press Syndicate in downtown Cairo to protest against the detention of journalists the previous day - 11 were arrested and later released - and what they called the police siege of the syndicate.
""Some have been killed in an attack by armed men against an Egyptian army force off the coast of Rafah [in North Sinai]"". No more information given.

Two lawyers were assaulted by officers from Dokki police station. Police forces also fired teargas at lawyers waiting outside a Cairo police station at about 10 pm on 25 April, after the station chief yelled at them to leave. The lawyers had been prevented from attending investigations with those who were detained during the protests.
A roadside bomb in the North Sinai town of El-Arish killed three Egyptian police conscripts on 27 April. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack.
Pensioners protest against social solidarity minister, threaten to go on hunger strikes.

A police officer injured a microbus driver after firing a shot at his leg following an altercation over the traffic. The police captain had a brawl with the driver in Alf Maskan neighborhood in eastern Cairo on 27 April. In an official statement, the ministry said a group of drivers interfered in the dispute and then assaulted and injured the police officer, which led to the officer pulling out his weapon against the microbus driver.

On 28 April, dozens of journalists marched from the Press Syndicates headquarters to the general prosecutors office to file a report against the arbitrary arrest and harassment of journalists and the 25 April siege of the syndicates headquarters. Journalists held banners calling for the release of their colleagues, while chanting, ""Journalism is not a crime.""

Yanair Gates editor-in-chief and a journalist started a sit-in outside the Press Syndicates headquarters in downtown Cairo on 30 April to protest security raids of their private residencies at dawn on Friday.

Lawyers and activists said that security forces assaulted detained protesters, injuring some of them, at the Red Mountain Central Security Forces Camp near Cairo on April 30 when they refused to be transferred to another prison before meeting prosecutors.

column16: AP; AFP; Daily News (Egypt); Aswat Masriya (Egypt)
column17: Around 50 Egyptian police stormed the headquarters of the journalists association in central Cairo on 1 May and arrested two journalists who had started a sit-in in protest at the headquarters of the union. Hundreds of workers from several provinces who came to hold a protest in Cairo for International Workers Day were also prevented from assembling by police. Tadamon coalition announced a protest would take place at the Press Syndicates headquarters in Cairos downtown to denounce legislation drafted by the government which it considers to be ""anti-worker"". Aswat Masriya reported that the security personnel assaulted the syndicates two people tasked with securing the syndicates building.
Journalists announced starting a sit-in at the syndicates headquarters in Cairo in protest to the security forces storming the syndicates building and ""kidnapping two colleagues"", on 1 May.

Egypts journalists union called for the dismissal of the interior minister and launched an open-ended sit-in at its headquarters in downtown Cairo on 2 May, protesting the detention of two journalists on its premises the previous night.

Some 200 people gathered outside the Journalists Syndicate building on 3 May, chanting slogans such as ""journalists are not militants"" - a reference to terrorism charges some media workers now face in Egypt. To commemorate World Press Freedom Day, several journalists covered their mouths with gags and bound their hands to protest Egypts media restrictions, while others hung a black banner from the buildings facade.

Medical sources in North Sinai said on 3 May that the security forces killed three militants and wounded four others in a shoot-out between a security detail and a group of gunmen that opened fire at a military checkpoint near Al -Arish. The source added that three soldiers were hurt in the attack and were taken to Al-Arish hospital.

A soldier was killed by an IED that targeted his armored vehicle that was accompanying a water supplement convoy sent to security checkpoints in Sheikh Zuweid on 3 May. Security forces also detonated three [Improvised Explosive Device] IEDs in an operation near Al-Shaykh Zuwayd and Rafah.

Around 3,000 Egyptian journalists demanded the sacking of the interior minister at the Journalists Syndicate on 4 May, after an unprecedented police raid to arrest two reporters. Members gathered and chanted ""the interior ministry are thugs"". A protesting journalist and Press Syndicate member said on his Facebook page on 4 May that he was assaulted by pro-government protesters near the Press Syndicate. Two Central Security Forces officers aided the journalist who surrounded him until they reached 26th July Street.

A few hundred students at the American University in Cairo (AUC) called for the immediate release of their detained colleague Ibrahim Tamer on 4 May. With ""Free Bebo"" shirts, flyers, and banners, students marched throughout the AUCs new campus in the Fifth Settlement on the outskirts of Cairo, chanting against the systematic detention of fellow students.
Al-Watan reported that protests took place over a social housing project. No location or exact date was given.

Police officers allegedly insulted, beat, and tortured a lawyer following his arrival to the police station on 6 May. On 5 May 2016, Egyptian security forces arrested the lawyer in Cairo's Maadi district and brought him to Shubra al-Kheima police station in northern Cairo. On May 7, his lawyers filed a complaint to several authorities, including the head judge of the Supreme Judicial Council, the prosecutor-general, the Lawyers Syndicate, and the National Council for Human Rights (NCHR). In the complaint, they say that police officers allegedly insulted, beat and tortured the human rights defender.

On 7 May, a police officer was reportedly injured by an IED that targeted his armoured vehicle as it was crossing Arish-Rafah International Road. The attack was believed to have been carried out by members of the State of Sinai.
Dozens of farmers in Dakahlia Governorate cut the road in Obaid over the wheat crisis.

column16: AP; Daily News (Egypt); AFP; Aswat Masriya (Egypt); Agence Tunis Afrique Presse
column17: Two militant groups, including the Islamic States affiliate in Egypt and Popular Resistance, claimed responsibility for an attack that killed eight policemen in the early hours of 8 May in Helwan in Greater Cairo. According to a statement by the interior ministry, four unidentified assailants with automatic weapons stopped a police vehicle carrying eight policemen dressed in civilian clothes. The policemen were inspecting the security situation in a Helwan district. The Islamic States affiliate in Egypt claimed responsibility for the attack and said that it comes as part of a series of attacks ""in retaliation"" for women's imprisonment in Egyptian jails. It was not possible to verify the statements, though most media reported the attack as being carried out by the Islamic State affilate group. According to a resident in the Daily News Egypt, the attack was carried out by members of the Arab Abu Maseid tribe, using a machine gun fixed on a truck.

A police officer and two soldiers were reportedly killed by an improvised explosive device (IED) that targeted their security vehicle on 9 May south of Al Arish, according to North Sinai-based journalist who preferred to remain anonymous.

A police officer and a solider were reportedly injured on 10 May when an improvised explosive device (IED) detonated in Al-Arish city in the North Sinai governorate. The bomb was placed near to al-Masaeed fuel station in Arish, and injured the two policemen who were inside the vehicle as they passed the bombs location, in addition to a citizen walking in the near vicinity of the station at the time of the explosion.

Pilots of EgyptAir held a four day go-slow protest which ended on 14 May demanding higher salaries, causing the delay of 37 flights. In an agreement reached with the airline and the Civil Aviation Minister, they were granted a 40 percent pay raise.

On 13 May, a number of residents in Al-Ashie village in Luxor set two police cars on fire and hurled stones at the officers, apparently in response to the arrest of two men riding a motorbike without license plates. Additional security forces were sent to the scene of the incident to ""control and disperse"" the angry crowd.
A Shiite citizen accused the national security agency in Alexandria of detaining him before and after he traveled to Iraq. He was tortured and given electric shocks whilst detained in May 2016.
An Egyptian conscript was killed and a police officer injured on 15 May after an explosive device went off during a security patrol in the Massaid area in Arish in North Sinai.

column6: Police Forces of Egypt (2014-) Prison Guards
