column17: On May 17, Freedom for the Brave, an independent activist group, reported that Central Giza Prison guards beat detainees in the first floor of the prison.
The ""Egypt is not for sale"" campaign launched by the Democratic Alliance party (Civil Democratic Current) announced on 17 May a symbolic open-ended sit-in inside Al-Karama party headquarters.
Journalists of the privately-owned Al-Fagr newspaper organised a stand of solidarity on the stairs of the Press Syndicate on 18 May to call for the release of their arrested coworker.

The workers General Petroleum Authority organised two rallies to protest continuing their work if the governments civil service law, which prohibits them from financial rights, is passed. The protesters claimed the Ministry of Finance rejected paying the workers their share of the profits for 2014, 2015 and the current year. Exact date not reported.

A leading tribal figure from the El-Fawkhriya tribe was executed by three masked militants who drove in on a motorbike and opened fire against him in front of his home in Al-Arish city in North Sinai governorate on 18 May. According to residents, the attack was carried out against the leading tribal figure due to his ongoing cooperation with state security forces against ""Sinai Province"" militants who are affiliated with the Islamic State (IS).

Arrests: Egyptian authorities arrested on 19 May a well-known advocate for the rights of Coptic Christians from his home in Cairo. The director of the Minority and Religious Groups Department of the Egyptian Commission for Rights and Freedoms was assaulted by police and taken in for interrogation by national security before he was given a four-day detention order.
On 19 May, militants hit a home in al-Zuwaraa village near Sheikh Zuweid with a mortar shell, killing seven. The attack was not claimed by any group.
Troops ambushed and killed a gunman on a motorbike in the southern region of Jura near Sheikh Zuweyid.

A 70-year-old Christian woman was dragged out of her home by a Muslim mob who beat her and insulted her before they stripped her off her clothes and forced her to walk through the streets as they chanted Allahu Akbar, or ""God is great."" The incident happened on 20 May after rumors spread that the elderly woman's son had an affair with a Muslim woman.
Forty-three insurgents were killed in raids in and around Arish, Sheikh Zuwaid and Rafah by Egyptian military and security forces on 20 May. Fatalities divided between three events.
Forty-three insurgents were killed in raids in and around Arish, Sheikh Zuwaid and Rafah by Egyptian military and security forces on 20 May. Fatalities divided between three events.

A Central Security Forces (CSF) officer was reportedly killed and two others injured during a security raid on 20 April to arrest the alleged perpetrators of the Helwan attack. The raid took place in the Ezbet El Walda area in the governorate of Helwan. The armed clashes between the CSF and alleged militants were reported to have lasted for nearly two hours. Three militants were killed and another three were arrested.

Military units from the Second and Third Field Armies, supported by the air force and civilian police, launched raids in the mountain areas in central Sinai as part of Operation Martyrs Right Three. Six insurgents and two commanders were killed in the Halal region in central Sinai.

Two people were injured and seven homes and a storage space were burnt after sectarian clashes between residents of the Minya province. The clashes took place after news of a romantic affair between a Christian worker and a Muslim woman broke out in the Karam village in Minya. A group of 300 Muslim residents were reported to have gathered in front of the Coptic Christian workers house and set it on fire, an act which ignited a larger set of clashes between the Muslim and Christian residents of the village. In response, a group of Christian residents gathered and set fire to more houses and a storage room that belong to the Muslim residents. Crowds were later controlled by security forces.

Forty-three insurgents were killed in raids in and around Arish, Sheikh Zuwaid and Rafah by Egyptian military and security forces on 20 May. Two other militants were also killed and one injured while they were trying to target a security patrol south of Sheikh Zuwaid. Fatalities divided between three events.
A Central Security Forces personnel was killed and a police sergeant injured when an explosive charge hit their armoured vehicle in Arish [North Sinai Governorate] on 21 May.

The Egyptian Armed Forces killed 85 militants during a four-day security campaign in the Sinai Peninsula. The army carried out military operations that included airstrikes on militant hideouts in North Sinais Sheikh Zuweid and Rafah. Fatalities divided between events in Rafah and Sheikh Zuweyid on 22 - 25 May.
Dozens of transferred teachers organised a protest on 22 May, calling on the Ministry of Education to relocate them to work in their governorates due to the long distances they have to commute.
Several political parties began a week-long sit-in on 22 May in the Socialist Popular Alliance party (SPAP) headquarters against the maritime demarcation deal between Egypt and Saudi Arabia.

From 22-23 May, a group of 26 workers in Alexandria Shipyard Company arranged an open sit-in. The workers arranged the sit-in to protest against unpaid wages over the past four years, the abolishment of national minimum wages just six months after its activation, and to call for annual pre-Ramadan bonuses.

The Egyptian Armed Forces killed 85 militants during a four-day security campaign in the Sinai Peninsula. The army carried out military operations that included airstrikes on militant hideouts in North Sinais Sheikh Zuweid and Rafah. Fatalities divided between events in Rafah and Sheikh Zuweyid on 22 - 25 May.

The Egyptian Armed Forces killed 85 militants during a four-day security campaign in the Sinai Peninsula. The army carried out military operations that included airstrikes on militant hideouts in North Sinais Sheikh Zuweid and Rafah. Fatalities divided between events in Rafah and Sheikh Zuweyid on 22 - 25 May.

The Egyptian Armed Forces killed 85 militants during a four-day security campaign in the Sinai Peninsula. The army carried out military operations that included airstrikes on militant hideouts in North Sinais Sheikh Zuweid and Rafah. Fatalities divided between events in Rafah and Sheikh Zuweyid on 22 - 25 May.

Dozens of transferred teachers continued an ongoing protest that began on 22 May, calling on the Ministry of Education to relocate them to work in their governorates due to the long distances they have to commute.

From 22-23 May, a group of 26 workers in Alexandria Shipyard Company arranged an open sit-in. The workers arranged the sit-in to protest against unpaid wages over the past four years, the abolishment of national minimum wages just six months after its activation, and to call for annual pre-Ramadan bonuses. On 23 May, when the workers arrived to work, they were banned from entering as military units were deployed.
An exchange of fire between police forces and an armed group near New Cairo on 23 May resulted in the death of two group members and left a third with injuries.

The Egyptian Armed Forces killed 85 militants during a four-day security campaign in the Sinai Peninsula. The army carried out military operations that included airstrikes on militant hideouts in North Sinais Sheikh Zuweid and Rafah. Fatalities divided between events in Rafah and Sheikh Zuweyid on 22 - 25 May.

The Egyptian Armed Forces killed 85 militants during a four-day security campaign in the Sinai Peninsula. The army carried out military operations that included airstrikes on militant hideouts in North Sinais Sheikh Zuweid and Rafah. Fatalities divided between events in Rafah and Sheikh Zuweyid on 22 - 25 May.

An Egyptian military officer and three soldiers were ""killed"" in an attack in North Sinai, according to Al-Jazeera TV. The channel did not mention how the attack took place or which group was involved.

The Egyptian Armed Forces killed 85 militants during a four-day security campaign in the Sinai Peninsula. The army carried out military operations that included airstrikes on militant hideouts in North Sinais Sheikh Zuweid and Rafah. Fatalities divided between events in Rafah and Sheikh Zuweyid on 22 - 25 May.

The Egyptian Armed Forces killed 85 militants during a four-day security campaign in the Sinai Peninsula. The army carried out military operations that included airstrikes on militant hideouts in North Sinais Sheikh Zuweid and Rafah. Fatalities divided between events in Rafah and Sheikh Zuweyid on 22 - 25 May. On May 25, the State of Sinai militant group claimed an attack on an Egyptian tank using a guided missile. While the attack was claimed by State of Sinai, it was not reported by the Egyptian military or news outlets.
26 workers of the Alexandria Shipyard Company who were imprisoned on 25 May on charges of protesting have reported being assaulted.

A group of police officers severely beat a workshop owner in Cairo on 25 May while he was being detained, and he was later pronounced dead at Al-Wayli police station in Abbasiya. The family of the workshop owner, accused the police of torturing him to death.

Dozens of post-graduate degree holders protested at Tahrir Square in downtown Cairo against their unemployment. The State Council later decided to grant Masters degree and PhD holders the right to a job.
Three soldiers were injured on 27 May as their military vehicle was targeted by an improvised explosive device (IED) east of El-Arish, near the bypass road Kharouba.

As many as 36 Islamist militants were killed in air strikes and military operations in Sinai over the past two days, the Armed Forces said Saturday [28 May]. They were targeted in Al-Arish, Rafah and Sheikh Zuwaid. Fatalities divided between events on 27 and 28 May.

As many as 36 Islamist militants were killed in air strikes and military operations in Sinai over the past two days, the Armed Forces said Saturday [28 May]. They were targeted in Al-Arish, Rafah and Sheikh Zuwaid. Fatalities divided between events on 27 and 28 May.

As many as 36 Islamist militants were killed in air strikes and military operations in Sinai over the past two days, the Armed Forces said Saturday [28 May]. They were targeted in Al-Arish, Rafah and Sheikh Zuwaid. Fatalities divided between events on 27 and 28 May.

Several social media pages affiliated to ""Sinai Province"" militant group circulated photos of a destroyed house in Al-Arish, which they claimed responsibility for exploding on 28 May. They also alleged that the house is owned by a major general in the police force and the attack was in response to recent state security operations carried out against militants.

As many as 36 Islamist militants were killed in air strikes and military operations in Sinai over the past two days, the Armed Forces said Saturday [28 May]. They were targeted in Al-Arish, Rafah and Sheikh Zuwaid. Fatalities divided between events on 27 and 28 May.

As many as 36 Islamist militants were killed in air strikes and military operations in Sinai over the past two days, the Armed Forces said Saturday [28 May]. They were targeted in Al-Arish, Rafah and Sheikh Zuwaid. Fatalities divided between events on 27 and 28 May.

As many as 36 Islamist militants were killed in air strikes and military operations in Sinai over the past two days, the Armed Forces said Saturday [28 May]. They were targeted in Al-Arish, Rafah and Sheikh Zuwaid. Fatalities divided between events on 27 and 28 May.

Three police conscripts were injured on 28 May in the al-Masaeed area, west of Arish, North Sinai, when a roadside bomb exploded as their police armored vehicle was passing by. Security sources were unable to identify the militants responsible for the attack.
On 29 May, a roadside bomb killed two police and wounded three conscripts south of Al-Arish in the northern part of the Sinai Peninsula.

The Egyptian Armed Forces continued the third stage of Operation Martyrs Right with reports of 16 militants being killed between 30 May - 31 May during checkpoint operations in Al-Arish, Rafah, and Sheikh Zuweid. Fatalities divided between events.

The Egyptian Armed Forces continued the third stage of Operation Martyrs Right with reports of 16 militants being killed between 30 May - 31 May during checkpoint operations in Al-Arish, Rafah, and Sheikh Zuweid. Fatalities divided between events.

The Egyptian Armed Forces continued the third stage of Operation Martyrs Right with reports of 16 militants being killed between 30 May - 31 May during checkpoint operations in Al-Arish, Rafah, and Sheikh Zuweid. Fatalities divided between events.

On 31 May, a roadside bomb struck a military armored vehicle in Qabr Omeir village in the al-Kharouba area near Sheikh Zuweid, killing six police conscripts. Although there was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack, it is believed that members of ""Sinai Province"" were involved.

The Egyptian Armed Forces continued the third stage of Operation Martyrs Right with reports of 16 militants being killed between 30 May - 31 May during checkpoint operations in Al-Arish, Rafah, and Sheikh Zuweid. Fatalities divided between events.

The Egyptian Armed Forces continued the third stage of Operation Martyrs Right with reports of 16 militants being killed between 30 May - 31 May during checkpoint operations in Al-Arish, Rafah, and Sheikh Zuweid. Fatalities divided between events.

The Egyptian Armed Forces continued the third stage of Operation Martyrs Right with reports of 16 militants being killed between 30 May - 31 May during checkpoint operations in Al-Arish, Rafah, and Sheikh Zuweid. Fatalities divided between events.

The Tadamon Coalition protested and chanted anti-government slogans in front of the Doctors Syndicate on 1 June against the decision by parliament to reject any discussion of the coalitions self-drafted civil service law.
Five people were injured in an explosion in Rafah, North Sinai, on 1 June. A baby girl was among the victims of the improvised explosive device, which went off in the Rafah neighborhood of Horeya.
Unidentified assailants bombed a mosque in North Sinais Al-Arish.

column16: Aswat Masriya (Egypt); Daily News (Egypt); Egypt Independent
column17: The Egyptian Armed Forces continued the third stage of Operation Martyrs Right with reports of 22 militants being killed between 1 - 2 June during checkpoint operations. Fatalities divided between events. Armed forces and civil police elements tightened measures in the areas of al-Shallaq, Qabr Emeir, Khat al-Gouza and Abu Zamat to ensure there are no militants there. Fatalities divided between 4 locations on each day.

Property destruction: The Electricity Ministry said that the Masaed-Sheikh Zuwayed power line in North Sinai came under attack from militants on 3 June, leading to blackouts in the Rafah and Sheikh Zuwayed areas.

Four employees from the National Social Insurance Authority were arrested from a protest in front of the Ministry of Social Solidarity headquarters. Their demands included raising employees salaries, amendments to regulations, and the dismissal of the authoritys advisers who they claim receive high salaries which impacts those of the employees. The employees were also protesting against the civil service draft law.

Military forces on 4 June thwarted a bid to attack security personnel in North Sinai. Two militants were spotted sneaking into a road-side house to plant an explosive device to attack forces patrolling the place. A military squad stormed the house and shot one of the militants down and injured the other.

A police conscript affiliated to the North Sinai security forces was injured when shot by unknown gunmen in Central Sinai. North Sinai security services were informed that the conscript was shot in his right foot while on duty at a security checkpoint in Central Sinai.

The Nile Cotton Ginning Company (NCGC) workers began a strike on 5 June in front of the Ministry of Commerce and Industry, to demand payment of late salaries for the past five months and implementation of the Administrative Court ruling to return the company to the authority of the public sector.

On 5 June, ""Sinai Province"" claimed responsibility for destroying a M113 tank and then clashing with the officers and conscripts who were inside it and the accompanying army platoon on the Al-Arish-Rafah International Road. The attack resulted in the destruction of a M113 tank by an improvised explosive device (IED). Following the explosion, clashes erupted between Sinai Province fighters and conscripts from the platoon. These clashes reportedly resulted in the death and injury of several army members.

Sinai Province militants reportedly managed to foil a military mission to storm a faction of ""Sinai Province"" in Sheikh Zuweid using armoured vehicles. The Armed Forces were met by tough resistance and their mission failed.

On June 6, Islamic State in Egypt and Popular Resistance Movement both claimed responsibility for a clash that took place in Mansoura between military forces and militants. Both Islamic State in Egypt and the Popular Resistance Movement posted separate official claims of responsibility. In their claim, the Popular Resistance Movement announced that the targets for the shootout were Brigadier General Hisham Salim and Major Ahmed al-Jumaili of the Investigations Department in Daqhalia. The attack injured two, including Salim's driver and another unnamed member of the force.
A police conscript was shot dead on 6 June by militants believed to be members of Islamic State-affiliated group ""Sinai Province"" in southern Rafah.

Three suspected perpetrators of the armed attack against troops from Helwan police station, which left eight personnel dead on 8 May, were shot dead during a police raid on 6 June. The Deputy Head of Damietta Security Department and three policemen were also reportedly killed and two other suspects were arrested at the scene, when police stormed an apartment in Ras al-Barr city, Damietta governorate.
A Central Security Forces conscript was killed by a bomb blast to the south of Sheikh Zuwaid city, North Sinai, on 7 June. The victim was killed while on patrol in the Karm al-Qawadis area.
Dozens of high school students and their parents staged protests outside the Education Ministry on 7 June against the leakage of high school exam papers this week.

Lawyers from Abu Kabir in Sharqeya Governorate gathered on 9 June inside the Abu Kabir court to express anger over the mistreatment of a prosecutor after he refused to settle an argument that erupted between one of the lawyers and a clerk inside the court.
An army conscript was killed on 10 June by anonymous militants in North Sinais Rafah in an attack that targeted El-Maswora checkpoint.

Defusal: Security forces succeeded in detonating three IEDs that were prepared to target armoured vehicles at Bir Ela-Hafn checkpoint. Forces also detonated three other IEDs planted south of Ala-Arish.
A total of three civilians were killed on 11 June in North Sinai by militants believed to belong to Islamic State (IS) affiliate ""Sinai Province"". One was killed in Al Arish.
A total of three civilians were killed on 11 June in North Sinai by militants believed to belong to Islamic State (IS) affiliate ""Sinai Province"". Two were killed south of Rafah.

Dozens of Egyptian students gathered around the Ministry of Education calling for Education Minister El-Helaly El-Sherbiny to resign and bring an end to the current university admissions system. The students raised their objections to the level of difficulty in an exam paper and the prevalance of exam cheating.
Dozens of workers in the Nile Cotton Ginning Company (NCGC) staged a protest Monday in front of Itihadiya Palace in Cairo demanding the return of their company to the ownership of the government.

Workers at Egypt Foods protested demanding annual bonuses, a raise in salaries, and the dismissal of certain managers on 15 June in the industrial area in the district of Quisna, Menufiya. They estimated that 1,500 workers are participating in the current strike. They went on strike four days later, on 19 June, after the company allegedly suspended 21 workers for staging the demonstration
Al-Shorouk reported that two militant attacks were foiled and 15 Islamist militants were killed in Sinais Sheikh Zuweid.

column16: Daily News (Egypt); Menastream; Tahrir News (Egypt); AP
column17: Four masked gunmen belonging to State of Sinai militant group stormed a house in the northern Sinai Peninsula city of al-Arish and shot dead two policemen on 16 June. The officers were killed inside their homes, which are located in the Masaeed district near an Arish police station.

A man was reported to have died in Al-Montazah police station located in Alexandria. The Egyptian Coordination of Rights and Freedoms (ECRF) said that the man who was detained on Friday on crime-related charges, died after police officers harshly assaulted him until he died. The Ministry of Interior did not confirm the death and did not provide further information about the incident.

On 17 June, a Muslim mob in the the village of Qaryat al Bayda in Amriya south of Alexandria waged a sectarian attack against the Copts in the village on suspicion that the Copts were turning a house owned by one of their community into a church. The Muslim mob gathered and, shouting Islamic slogans against the Copts, throwing stones at Coptic-owned houses in the village. They attempted to destroy the building and the construction material that was being used to erect the house. They assaulted and injured two Coptic men.

At least 30 alleged State of Sinai militants were killed and another 40 injured in Egyptian Air Force strikes on 18 June. The militants, who escaped Sheikh Zuwaid city and relocated to the area of Mazarei Gehad abu Tabl, were targeted south of Arish city, near to the international airport

A policeman was killed and another injured on 19 June in a road-side bomb explosion in central Sinai. The explosion took place as security personnel passed by Al-Hasna- Sadr Hitan road, in the district of Al-Hasna police station. The attack is believed to have been executed by the Islamic State-affiliated militant group ""Sinai Province"", who are centralised mainly in North Sinai and other nearby regions.
A policeman in the Northern Sinai town of Arish was was killed in front of his home on 19 June after anonymous militants shot him.

On 20 June, a non-commissioned officer was killed south of Al-Arish, after militants stormed his home and opened fire against him. Three militants executed the operation using a truck and confiscated his service weapons amongst other personal belongings. The Ministry of Interior did not publish any statement regarding the incident.

Two police officers were killed inside their homes in the Masaeed district in Al-Arish, near a police station. Four anonymous gunmen attacked them and opened fire in their homes, according to the Ministry of Interiors official statement following the attack.
A conscript from among the North Sinai security troops was shot and injured on 21 June by unknown perpetrators whilst caring out security raids south of Rafah.
A policeman died of gunshot wounds he sustained in an attack in Al-Arish on Tuesday [21 June].

A police officer and five conscripts were injured on 21 June due to an improvised explosive device (IED) attack executed against their armoured vehicle in central Sinai. The armoured vehicle was part of a carding operation in the Al Qessima region in central Sinai.

A senior non-commissioned officer was killed on 21 June evening in his house near Al-Arish. Four militants believed to be members of Sinai Province, a movement affiliated with Islamic State (IS), stormed the policemans home and killed him.
A conscript was injured in a bomb blast 17km west of Arish on 21 June.
A police sergeant was killed and another wounded when gunmen opened fire at them in Arish in northern Sinai, a security source told MENA Wednesday [ 22 June].

Two army conscripts were killed and three injured on 25 June due to the explosion of an improvised explosive device (IED) that targeted their armored vehicle in the city of Sheikh Zuweid in North Sinai. Militants believed to be members of Islamic State (IS)-affiliated group Sinai Province targeted the armored vehicle in El Gowra area of Sheikh Zuweid in North Sinai.

A conscript from the North Sinai security troops was shot dead by a sniper on 26 June while standing on duty at a checkpoint in the area of al-Goura, south of Sheikh Zuwaid. Officials from the armies media office denied the news.

During the postponement of an appeal case of Tiran and Sanafir islands in the Supreme Administrative Court on 26 June, attendees and activists in the court room chanted ""The islands are Egyptian"", ""We don't want the Saudi Bridge"", and ""Malek Adly is free"".

Hundreds of Egyptian high school students gathered outside the Education Ministry on 27 June to protest against exam cancellations and postponements. The students demanded the sacking of the education minister, the abolition of the university admissions system, and the holding accountable of those involved in the leakage of high school exams. Central Security Forces fired tear gas at the students to disperse their protest in downtown Cairo. The protesters later moved to Tahrir Square.
Students staged protests on 27 June in Assiut, Alexandria, and Suez calling for the Education ministers immediate dismissal after a series of exam leaks.
Students staged protests on 27 June in Assiut, Alexandria, and Suez calling for the Education ministers immediate dismissal after a series of exam leaks.
Students staged protests on 27 June in Assiut, Alexandria, and Suez calling for the Education ministers immediate dismissal after a series of exam leaks.

Approximately 20 suspended workers announced an open-ended strike inside the Egyptian Trade Union Federations (ETUF) headquarters. The employees are protesting against the states policy on workers rights. The protestors have been suspended from the Egypt Iran Company for Textiles, Misr Shebin El-Kom Spinning and Weaving, and Nile Cotton Ginning Company.
Ultras Ahlawy members clashed with security forces outside the Borg-Al Arab stadium in Alexandria on 28 June.

Security forces dispersed a protest by high school students near the Education Ministry on 29 June, forcing them to move to a new protest location at Mounira Preparatory School in Sayeda Zeinab. Protesters demanded the ministers resignation whilst others refused to retake exams.

A Muslim mob waged an attack against the Copts in the village of Koum Al-Loufy, after a resident circulated a rumour that a new church would be built in the village. The Muslim mob set fire to houses and clashed with the police.
A police officer was killed and two conscripts from the Central Security Forces injured in an IED blast in Rafah City, North Sinai, on 29 June.

In Port Fuad, a twin city of Port Said on the northern tip of the Suez Canal, a suspected militant stabbed to death a police colonel outside his home, according to the security officials. The policeman served in Port Saids security headquarters, said the officials.
A soldier wounded by an earlier bomb blast was wounded again when an ambulance taking him to el-Arish, escorted by an armored vehicle, was ambushed by militants. Another soldier was killed.
In a village near the border town of Rafah, a bomb blast badly wounded a soldier.
Islamist militants gunned down a Christian priest in North Sinais Al Arish as he was fixing his car on 30 June.

One policeman was killed and three wounded when an improvised bomb exploded as their convoy drove near a police station in Al Arish on 30 June. Islamic State affiliate group State of Sinai claimed responsibility.
In July 2016, two brothers aged 16 and 19 years old were detained in Rafah by military forces. They were never found following their detention. (date unclear, coded as July 1st)
Two military personnel were injured in a roadside bomb explosion targeting an armored vehicle in Rafah, North Sinai, on 2 July.

Four people were killed while eight others injured in a feud between two clans in Minya, south of Cairo. The armed clash, in which firearms were used, was triggered by a quarrel between members of Kheir and Awlad Ibrahim families due to previous differences, including the sexual harassment of a woman, in Reida village of Minya township.
Students protest in front of the headquarters of the Ministry of Education on 4 July. A police officer was videoed assaulting a thanaweyya amma secondary school student (no reports of injuries).
Security forces in Luxor freed a young man after 24 hours of his abduction by unidentified persons.

Over the last week, two young men were reportedly killed in shootings similar or in kidnappings in North Sinai after which they were beheaded. The men were kidnapped by militants acussed of being army collaborators and part of Group 103 which provides information to the army on militant checkpoint positions.

Two unidentified gunmen opened fire on a car on the Cairo-Alexandria desert road in the Wadi al-Natrun area. The driver was reported killed in the attack and his son was injured. A nun was also reported killed in the attack as the car carrying her along with two other nuns and a doctor happened to be passing during the attack. The Egyptian Interior Ministry denies the killing. Some reports say the victim was a police officer, though this is not confirmed.

Two civilians were killed and one injured in a mortar shell attack that struck their family home in Rafah on 7 July. The mortar was launched by Islamic State-affiliated group Sinai Province and was reportedly targeting a security checkpoint but instead landed on the civilians house, destroying it completely.

Defusal: The Egyptian Armed Forces successfully detonated five improvised explosive devices (IED) on 8 July south of Sheikh Zuweid. The Islamic State-affiliated group ""Sinai Province"" is believed to be responsible for planting IEDs such as these in order to target army and police stationing points and armoured patrols.

A young man was killed on 8 July inside his home in Sheikh Zuweid, North Sinai by members of the militant group ""Sinai Province"". He was targeted and shot over claims by militants that he was a leading figure in a group which collaborates with the army by providing information about ""Sinai Province"" members.

Local media circulated reports of a successful military campaign in Sinai, leading to the killing of a leading figure of the Sinai Province. The campaign included air strikes that carried out several raids and targeted Mohessin. The Armed Forcess media office confirmed the military campaign that targeted militants from Sinai Province, without giving exact names of the targets or the number of those killed. Mohamed Moussa Mohessin, who was allegedly killed in February in central Sinai, was reportedly killed in the army campaign.
A low ranking police officer was killed in Arish, North Sinai, on 9 July by unknown assailants.

The Egyptian Armed Forces killed on Sunday 14 militants and arrested 12 others after forces succeeded in intercepting a planned ambush on a security checkpoint by militants in Sheikh Zuweid. The militants had three shotguns, two bombs, and 234 rounds in their possession.

Hundreds of Aswan-based teachers staged a demonstration on Sunday, in opposition to the governments delay in issuing a 200% incentive which was already approved by the Ministry of Education. The demonstration reached the Teachers Syndicate headquarters in Aswan, where the participants chanted against the Ministry of Finance and the Aswan governorate for not applying the Ministry of Educations orders.

Militants from the Islamic State (IS)-affiliated group Sinai Province bombed a local municipality headquarter early on Sunday in North Sinais Al-Arish. Residents from the village told that the explosion, caused by planted improvised explosive devices (IED), resulted in the full destruction of the headquarters. The attack on El-Sabils local municipality headquarters came after the army had used it as a base to target militants during its latest operation

A brigadier general and a conscript from the Egyptian police force died from an armoured car explosion in Al-Arish in the early hours of Monday morning. The bomb was allegedly planted on the side of the road and detonated remotely. So far, no group has claimed responsibility for the attack. A captain succumbed to his injuries one day after.

The family of Mahmoud Hamed accused security personnel from the Housh Eissa police station of assaulting their relative, leading to his death, while arresting him on Tuesday. The Ministry of Interior said on Tuesday that a police force, headed by Captain Ahmed Al-Sisi, arrested Hamed from his residency in Housh Eissa in Beheira. The family said Hamed was beaten to death by Al-Sisi and fellow officers. Al-Shehab Centre for Human Rights cited sources in the Housh Eissa hospital, saying that once Hameds body arrived at the hospital, security forces also came ""fearing anyone would take a picture of the body"". The Ministry of Interior told Daily News Egypt that the hospital report read that Hamed died from a heartattack and did not have any ""apparent signs [of torture] on his body"".
Last week, in a village in Minya region, Kom al-Lufi, a group of hard-liner Muslims attacked and torched houses of Christians after a similar rumor.

On Saturday, a group of Muslims attacked and torched houses of Christians in Nazlat Abu Yaqoub, located in the town of Manshaat al-Dahab in the Minya district, following a rumor that a Christian intended to turn a kindergarten into a church. Security forces arrested at least 14 people, while five Coptic homes were destroyed and set on fire.

A senior police officer in Tameyya villages security bureau in Fayoum was killed on Saturday afternoon after being targeted by unidentified assailants. Militants opened fire while they police officers a police car in Tameyya. The two other police officers were injured and were taken to the nearest hospital for treatment. A second police officer died on Monday of his wounds.
In the village of Edmo, in Minya, five people were injured from both Muslim and Christian parties, followed by the detention of individuals from both sides.

The families of the detained Egyptians in Libya protested at the Foreign Affairs Ministry headquarters in Downtown Cairo, demanding the government help release their relatives. Dozens of family members held pictures of their relatives and banners calling for their release in a silent protest.

Eighty members of Ultras Ahlawy were arrested on Sunday evening on charges of rioting at a match between Al-Ahly FC and Moroccan club El-Wedad in Borg Al-Arab stadium in Alexandria, according to state-run newspaper Al-Ahram. Police forces arrested the fans who had reportedly smashed stadium seats, destroyed two police cars, and threw stones at police officers resulting in the injury of three policemen and five conscripts.

A Muslim mob in southern Egypt stabbed a Coptic Christian to death over a personal feud in the village of Tahna al-Gabal late Sunday. A Coptic Christian was killed and the father of one of the priests was wounded. Police said they arrested four people in connection to the incident.

Hundreds of supporters of Port Saids Al-Masri FC, known as Green Eagles, marched this week near the cities Maryam Mosque in protest against the detention of their coach, Hossam Hassan, a legendary player and Egypts all-time top scorer. Local media reported that 30 protesters were arrested. Ibrahim was accused of assaulting a police officer at the end of his clubs last match of the season. Repeated protests in the city are laden with soccers tangled involvement and key role in the 2011 popular revolt that toppled president Hosni Mubarak

Three masters degree holders were kept in custody for 24 hours after security forces arrested them while protesting in front of the parliament headquarters. They protested against the states negligence towards them and the difficulty for them to get employed in the government.

After the killing of a Coptic Christian in Minya governorate, mourners gathered on Monday, at a local church for prayers for the dead and protests. Marching to the graveyard, they chanted ""with blood and soul, we redeem the cross.""
Asim village in Minya witnessed clashes between Muslims and Christians on July 19, after a young Muslim man went swimming naked in front of a Christian woman in the Bahr Yussef canal.

Clashes broke out between police and militants at the Sheikh Zuweid police station, resulting in the death of five militants. The militants attacked the station, and police forces retaliated with random gunfire.

Four police personal died after suffering various injuries in an explosion early Wednesday in North Sinai. There are also unconfirmed reports of one civilian death. Militants planted an explosive device on a police vehicle as it drove along the corniche of Al-Arish, later detonating it.
Two security force conscripts were shot dead in Al-Borag in central Sinai, during violent clashes with Beit Al-Maqdis militants, who had attempted to attack a police vehicle.

Several attacks took place across North Sinai on Thursday, injuring five conscripts, one non-commissioned officer, and one citizen. Another bomb detonated near an army-armoured vehicle on Al-Kharouba village road in Sheikh Zuweid, injuring two other conscripts.

Several attacks took place across North Sinai on Thursday, injuring five conscripts, one non-commissioned officer, and one citizen. A bomb exploded near Rafah in North Sinai, targeting an army-armoured vehicle and injuring a non-commissioned officer and two conscripts.

Several attacks took place across North Sinai on Thursday, injuring five conscripts, one non-commissioned officer, and one citizen. Another conscript was wounded in the explosion of an army-armoured vehicle.

Several attacks took place across North Sinai on Thursday, injuring five conscripts, one non-commissioned officer, and one citizen. A citizen was shot in his thigh by unknown suspects in Hafn area, south of Al-Arish

Clashes broke out on 22 July between Muslims and Christian over alleged illegal church-building. Mobs in Saft al-Kharsa village, on the outskirts of Fashn town, attacked a building under construction on Friday afternoon after a rumor went round that it was to be an unlicensed church. The attack led to the destruction a Christian mans house and a car.

Security forces in North Sinai reportedly killed 15 militants and injured another 12 following clashes on 23 July. Al-Watan reported that a militant cell raided a school near Rafahs border as they were being chased by security forces. The forces then put the school under siege and clashes broke out between the militants and security forces.

An Egyptian police officer was shot dead by unknown militants on 24 July. A deputy sheriff was targeted by an attacker near a police station in al-Arish city, the provincial capital of North Sinai. The Islamic State (IS)-affiliated Sinai Province claimed responsibility for the attack.

A tuktuk driver died on 24 July inside Tahta police station in Sohag after allegedly being assaulted and tortured by officers from the Investigation Bureau. He had been arrested on 16 July, after being accused of killing the village chief of a district called Al-Sheikh Zin Al-Din.

Security forces dispersed a protest on 25 July organised by more than a dozen women demanding to know the whereabouts of their children who were allegedly ""forcibly disappeared"". The women were protesting in front of the headquarters of the National Council for Human Rights (NCHR) in Giza.
An army conscript was killed after being targeted by a sniper while being on service at an army checkpoint south of Al-Arish on 25 July.

Not far from Sahel El-Tina, a police conscript was killed and 11 others were injured on 25 July by an explosion caused by an improvised explosives device (IED) that targeted an armoured police vehicle that was in a operation south of Sheikh Zuweid.

Demonstrations began on 25 July when new owners of social housing units in the Dahshur area demonstrated in front of the Armed Forces Engineering Authoritys technical office against the lack of basic services.

Two Ethiopian asylum seekers allegedly set themselves on fire on 26 July in front of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) office located in 6th October City. Information surrounding the situation remains unclear, but the incidents reportedly took place as part of a protest led by Ethiopias Oromo community that sought to demand the right to seek asylum with the UNHCR. One death reported.
A reporter covering the clashes between rioters and police in Imbaba, was assaulted by the police, and then arrested along with scores of relatives and residents from the neighbourhood.

Security forces were deployed in Giza to disperse rioting crowds accusing police of killing a man and throwing his body into the River Nile. The crowd gathered around the Imbaba police station on 26 July, after a suspect was killed during a police chase on Sunday. His family said he was killed by the police. The crowd gathered in front of the police station to demand the burial permit.

Three people were killed in an explosive device blast in Assamran district, south of Arish city in North Sinai. The three people were reported to be militants. State-run newspaper Al-Ahram reported that one police conscript and three citizens were killed by the explosion.
The Third Field Army troops managed to kill three Islamist militants in an exchange of fire in Wadi Khoriza in Sinai on 28 July.

Two police conscripts were killed and another five injured in an improvised explosive device (IED) attack on Friday in Al-Qessima in North Sinai. The attack targeted an armoured security vehicle that was involved in a sweeping operation to arrest wanted militants from the Islamic State (IS) affiliated group Sinai Province. Militants opened fire on conscripts directly after the explosion took place.
Dotmsr journalists protest mass layoff.

Residents of the village of Mazloum reacted angrily to the use of police force, mobbing and taking captive the policeman who had used a firearm. Central Security Forces were dispatched to the village to restore order and free the policeman. Villagers hurled stones at the police, who responded by firing teargas to subdue the violence.

One citizen was killed, and two others injured by police in Mazloum village, Daqahliya province, in an attempted arrest that turned into a deathly clash between police and villagers. Police forces stormed a house in the village to carry out the arrest of a male suspect when the suspects family interfered, refusing to turn him in and attempting to help him escape. A violent confrontation arose during which an officer opened fire.
On Sunday, a police officer was shot dead by unknown militants near a police station in Arish city of restive North Sinai province.
Masked gunmen killed a police conscript in a drive-by shooting in Kerdasa district of Giza on 2 August. 5 civilians were also injured in the attack.

A number of journalists gathered inside the Press Syndicate headquarters to express solidarity with a journalist who was detained in late April, whose health is deteriorating in detention. The journalists were holding signs reading #Al-Saqa_is_in_risk and #Press_is_not_crime.

An Egyptian air strike killed the head of the Islamic State group along with at least 45 other militants south of Al-Arish. The armies announcement did not say when the operation took place but named the head of the Egyptian affiliate of the group based in the Sinai Peninsula as Abu Doaa al-Ansari. The report could not be confirmed and an Egyptian expert on the Sinai insurgency, said that the military did not provide al-Ansaris real name, which casts doubts on the purported leaders identity and the report of his death. The officials also suggested that the 45 who were mentioned in the military spokesmans statement as killed alongside al-Ansari, may have perished in a series of airstrikes earlier this week that targeted IS positions and ammunition depots near the border town of Rafah.
Two people were killed while five others injured when a bomb exploded at el Bahr street in Arish city of North Sinai Governorate. Daily News Egypt reported 4 fatalities.
A group of residents crowded in front of the hospital in protest against the fragile security situation in the Al-Arish area on 5 August.

Egypts former grand mufti survived an assassination attempt on 5 August that left one person injured after a gun-battle with Islamist militants. His bodyguards exchanged fire with the attackers, who escaped in the car. The attack occurred in 6 October City, leaving one bodyguard in hospital with a gunshot wound to the foot. The Hasam Movement claimed responsibility for the attack.

On Sunday, four residents from Al-Arish were killed and another three were injured when an IED detonated on Al-Bahr Street, targeting a military patrol. Sinai Province is believed to be responsible for planting the IED in an attempt to target a military patrol.
A group of residents gathered in front of the Al-Arish hospital in protest to the fragile security situation in the area.

One resident and five police conscripts sustained wounds on Monday [8 August] when a bomb went off in al-Arish in North Sinai. It is believed that the attack was carried out by the Islamic State (IS)-affiliated group Sinai Province.

An army officer was killed and another three conscripts injured on Tuesday evening when an improvised explosive device (IED) that targeted their armoured vehicle was detonated west of Rafah in North Sinai governorate.
A police officer and another four conscripts, in addition to a civilian, were injured in an IED explosion that targeted an armoured police vehicle west of Al-Arish.

Copts who fled the village of Kom Al-Lufi in Samallout, Minya held a sit-in inside a church to pressure authorities to meet demands related to their legal rights in the aftermath of a sectarian incident in June, rejecting customary reconciliation with the attackers. They also protested the lack of response to their demands for law enforcement and proper compensation for their losses.
A Lawyer and member of the Lawyers Administrative Council in Port Said claimed that a non-commissioned police officer assaulted him along with two ""thugs"" in Port Said.

19 militants and 2 civilians were killed in North Sinai on Wednesday, amid clashes between security forces and militants near a security checkpoint in Sheikh Zuweid. The civilians were in the vicinity of the clashes. Anonymous militants reportedly attacked the security checkpoint of Abu Tawila.

Clashes were renewed in Minyas town of Samalut on Thursday. According to Copts Today website, three people were arrested and three others are wanted in the village of Abadeya El-Sherei following sectarian clashes. The incident was reported to have begun as a dispute between a Muslim and a Coptic man regarding the ownership of a piece of land. The incident escalated as a fight erupted during a reconciliation session.
The new owners of social housing units in Dahshour in 6th of October City demonstrated on 12 August against the refusal of banks to deliver the units before paying a maintenance deposit.
A group of activists and MPs staged a protest at Dar al-Qadaa al-Ali, a prominent judicial institution in downtown Cairo, on 13 August against sectarian violence in Minya governorate.

On the 14 August, the apartment of a non-commissioned police officer was bombed in Al-Sabeel district in North Sinai, but no casualties were reported. The residence was bombed after a number of unidentified suspects planted bombs under the three-storey building. Parts of three nearby buildings also sustained damages.

A police officer was killed in a landmine explosion in the town of Arish in North Sinai on 15 August. Security forces were combing the area around a police station in Arish after a group of militants were seen planting an explosive device. They exchanged fire with the militants and a landmine went off during the clash.

Three conscripts and two citizens were killed in a mortar attack on a truck transporting water on 15 August in Sheikh Zuweid in North Sinai. In a separate report, it was claimed that army forces destroyed a truck bomb driven by militants, targeting an army checkpoint in Sheikh Zuweid. A militant drove a truck bomb towards the checkpoint. The truck was immediately destroyed by an RBG shell launched by a conscript inside the checkpoint. After the truck exploded, officers and conscripts started exchanging fire with a number of militants. The exchange of fire left the militants dead.
A bomb exploded near Sheikh Zuweid, but no casualties were reported.
Directly after a truck bomb attack, joint forces from the army and police - including air forces - launched a security sweep in Sheikh Zuweid and Al-Arish, destroying a number of militant stations.

column16: AFP; AP; Egypt Independent; Daily News (Egypt)
column17: Two security personnel were killed on 21 August when gunmen attacked al-Egeizy security checkpoint, located on a regional road outside Sadat city, Menoufia. The newly-established militant group, Lewaa El-Thawra (Revolution Brigade) claimed responsibility.

A police and army officer were killed in central Al-Arish city on 23 August at dawn after anonymous militants opened fire on their vehicle. The two officers were targeted by militants while they were in a private car in the centre of North Sinais Al-Arish city.

Security forces killed an armed man on 24 August after he allegedly attacked a policeman in front of the Virgin Mary Church in Nozha, Eastern Cairo. Most reports stated that the motive and identity of the attacker were unclear; MENA news agency reported that a Muslim Brotherhood member was behind the attack.

A police driver kidnapped on 24 August was publicly shot dead on 25 August by suspected militants from the local Islamic State affiliate in Sinai. Three masked militants and the policeman arrived at the residential al-Masaeed district of the coastal city of el-Arish in a green pickup truck. The policeman, blindfolded with his arms and legs tied by a robe, was then brought out and shot twice in the head before the militants returned to the car and sped away.

Six militants were killed by security forces on 25 August in an attack on the Al-Masoura security checkpoint in Rafah city. Four of security personnel were injured in the gunfight and transferred to hospital for treatment. Aswat Masriya reported that Six Ansar beit Al-Maqdis (State of Sinai) militants were killed in Rafah and Sheikh Zuweid.
Egyptian armed forces killed four Islamist militants in an exchange of fire North Sinais Rafah on 26 August. The militants were targeting al-Nafora checkpoint.

Following the shooting of a microbus driver, his colleagues in the Arab Al-Maadi microbus stop staged a strike, demanding justice. The strike caused severe traffic and congestion in the area but was quelled by the police who threatened drivers and demanded that they keep working.

A microbus driver was shot dead by a non-commissioned police officer on 29 August in the Maadi district of Cairo. A policeman from Al-Sharabia police station shot a microbus driver dead after he refused to give the officer a ride for a ""work errand"", leading to an argument during which the driver was shot in the head. The Ministry of Interior claimed the officer was on duty and intervened to break up a fight at the microbus stop, where he fired a warning shot that hit the victim.

A medical student died on 29 August after being arrested by police forces, with his family accusing the security apparatus of torturing him to death. Police claimed that the student was arrested in a brothel in Nasr City and died during a police raid.
Two police conscripts were injured on 29 August as a gunman opened fire on a security checkpoint located on Haram Street in Giza.
El-Shorouk reported that an airstrike killed 16 militants in Sheikh Zuwayd on 30 August.
The army killed two militants after following their movements in southern Rafah.

Four soldiers were injured during military operations against militants in North Sinai on 31 August. The operations took place in Rafah and Sheikh Zuweid. The soldiers were transferred to Al-Arish hospital.
Defusal: Armed Forces successfully detonated seven bombs planted on the roads in North Sinai, without casualties.
At least two soldiers were reported dead and five other injured in an attack in North Sinai on 1 September. The attack took place in Al-Arish, after a road bomb exploded under their vehicle.
Dozens marched in a funeral in Sharqeya, while chanting against the police and the government.

A medical student in Al-Azhar University has been arrested in a raid on Al-Jadid village in Sharqeya and then found dead. He was known to participate in pro-Morsi demonstrations. Dozens marched in a funeral in Sharqeya, while chanting against the police and the government.

Dozens of mothers staged a protest on 1 September against a shortage of subsidized infant milk as well as rising prices, which is primarily being imported by the Egyptian Pharmaceutical Trading Company in Cairo.
A police sergeant and a citizen were killed in Arish on 1 September after an explosive device went off at a bridges entrance in the northern Sinai city.
The Rafah and Sheikh Zuwayed areas of North Sinai were hit by blackouts on 3 September after a power line was hit by gunfire as police were pursuing militants in the area.
Defusal: A 30-kg high explosive bomb was defused in el-Arish city of North Sinai.
A policeman shot a microbus driver in the foot in 6th October city.

Three police officers were injured while attempting to dismantle a bomb in Damietta. Those injured included a civil protection colonel, a conscript, and a non-commissioned police officer. Two identified suspects opened fire and ran away after throwing a bag full of batteries on the road. No militant group has claimed responsibility for the attack.

On 5 September, the Egyptian Armed Forces and police divisions launched a massive security campaign through which they succeeded in killing between 40- 60 Sinai Province militants in North Sinai in ground assaults and airstrikes executed by the Air Force south of Rafah. Whilst several media reports commented on the event, the information has not been verified.

Egypts armed forces said on 6 September that a total of 11 Islamist militants were killed and 5 others were injured in a shootout with security forces in al-Arish, Rafah and Sheikh Zuweid in North Sinai. Two were killed in Sheilh Zuweid

Egypts armed forces said on 6 September that a total of 11 Islamist militants were killed and 5 others were injured in a shootout with security forces in al-Arish, Rafah and Sheikh Zuweid in North Sinai. Two were killed in Sheilh Zuweid

Egypts armed forces said on 6 September that a total of 11 Islamist militants were killed and 5 others were injured in a shootout with security forces in al-Arish, Rafah and Sheikh Zuweid in North Sinai. In Sheikh Zuweiyd militants attacked a bomb squad that was in the process of detonating two improvised explosive devices (IED). In the ensuing clashes, two militants were killed. Not far away from Sheikh Zuweid , a police conscript was also reportedly killed during a security sweep south of the city. Lastly three police conscripts were killed and six others injured in a militant attack that targeted an army patrol south of Sheikh Zuweid.

The South Sinai deputy security director and five police officers were injured by heavy fire from anonymous militants during a security sweep. The security sweep was being conducted by police forces, in cooperation with the army, in Wadi Feran, Abou Redis city.
Masked gunmen shot dead a low-ranking police officer as he was leaving his house in the Al-Bashayer area of 6th October City on 8 September.

Security authorities announced the killing of 12 militants and the destruction of 64 hideouts in an extended crackdown in North Sinai on 9 September. Security forces launched a major operation covering south Arish, Sheikh Zuweid and Rafah. 4 fatalities recorded.

Security authorities announced the killing of 12 militants and the destruction of 64 hideouts in an extended crackdown in North Sinai on 9 September. Security forces launched a major operation covering south Arish, Sheikh Zuweid and Rafah. 4 fatalities recorded.

Security authorities announced the killing of 12 militants and the destruction of 64 hideouts in an extended crackdown in North Sinai on 9 September. Security forces launched a major operation covering south Arish, Sheikh Zuweid and Rafah. 4 fatalities recorded.

Dozens of prisoners who are being held in detention in Al-Salam police station set their cell on fire early on Saturday in an attempt to escape. However, security forces hindered the attempt. Clashes erupted between the detainees families and security forces; the latter allegedly used tear gas to disperse the families.

A police vehicle was targeted by an improvised explosive device (IED) on 12 September in the North Sinai city of Al-Arish. The IED was planted in the Geser El-Wadi suburb in central Al-Arish, and the explosion caused no injuries or deaths.

Two Coptic Christians were injured during a fight between Muslims and Christians in the village of Assem in Minya on 12 September. The police said that the reason of the fight was undetermined, and that it included only youth.
A man suspected of killing a police sergeant in Qaliubiya was killed in an exchange of fire with police in Alexandria on 12 September.

An army patrol was met with heavy fire on 18 September during a security sweep of El-Gowra village near Sheikh Zuweid city in North Sinai. The attack was launched by militants who are believed to be members of the ""Sinai Province"" militant group. No injuries.
Clashes between security personnel and a militant group near Rafah city. The clashes resulted in the death of one conscript and the injury of another.
In El-Hasna region of central Sinai, an armoured army vehicle was targeted by an improvised explosive device (IED) that resulted in the death of a conscript and the injury of another.

Dozens of teachers staged a demonstration in front of the Press Syndicate on 20 September in objection of the poor conditions of Egypts education sector and to demand the resignation of Education Minister El-Helaly El-Sherbiny.

A police conscript was killed on 21 September during violent clashes that erupted between militants and police forces near Sheikh Zuweid police station. Heavy fire erupted between police forces at the station and militants who are believed to be members of the Islamic State-affiliated group ""Sinai Province"".

In a separate incident in Al-Arish, four citizens were injured as gunmen opened fire at their vehicle. All the casualties were taken to hospital. No further details of the incident have been supplied.
A policeman died and another two were wounded when unidentified men opened fire at them in Al Arish in North Sinai on 22 September.
Three residents were kidnapped near their homes in El-Maswora, south of Rafah city, on 23 September.

Several local media outlets reported that security forces in North Sinai carried out a military campaign against ""Sinai Province"" stationing points south of Al-Arish and Sheikh Zuweid cities. This campaign reportedly resulted in the death of eight militants, in addition to four others in a truck transporting arms, which was used to attack army and police checkpoints.
A non-commissioned police officer was allegedly killed on 24 September and other two police officers injured in Al-Arish city.

In Gharbiya governorate, parents of primary school pupils protested against the poor hygiene and overcrowded classes in state schools. Parents chanted slogans against the education minister and the governor of Gharbiya.

In Qena, hundreds of high school students protested at the Governorate Building against the closure of the private tuition classes. Protesters said that classes in government schools are overcrowded, forcing them to seek better quality instruction through private tuition arrangements. Security forces were deployed around the building in case the protests turn violent.
After a policeman shot dead a cafe owner dozens of his relatives gathered outside the hospital, angrily demanding that the officer be put on trial.

A police officer in the governorate of Sharqeya shot dead a man on 25 September. The victim was the owner of a small local cafe in the village of Al-Haswa. While he was on shift, police forces stormed into the cafe and started searching him and the cafes clients. The officer then pulled out his side arm and shot him.
A civilian was killed and six others injured when a bomb went off on the Rafah-Sheikh Zuweid road.

Residents in Kafr Hemeid, Ayat, Giza governorate, staged a sit-in and a mob of locals burnt trees around the house of a businessman after a tiger escape from its enclosure and killed a local girl. They demanded the farm's operations are closed down and the culprit brought to justice.

Islamic State militants killed five Egyptian civilians and dumped their bodies, wearing orange jumpsuits, near the Abu Arafat district, south of Rafah city. Two of the men were beheaded and the others shot in the head over accusations they had collaborated with the Egyptian army.

The militant group ""Sinai Province"" claimed it targeted an army infantry patrol on 26 September using several improvised explosive devices (IED) in the Abu Refai region south of Sheikh Zuweid city. The group asserted that the operation resulted in the death and injury of several army officers and conscripts, though this was not confirmed.
A police officer and two conscripts were injured by an IED that detonated in Rafah city.
Three journalists who were arrested outside the Journalists Syndicate were beaten and electrocuted while in custody.
Dozens of post-graduate degree holders organised a protest on Tuesday in front of the headquarters of the cabinet, demanding employment in the Ministry of Higher Education and other government jobs.

Gunmen killed three Egyptian policeman and a civilian. The gunmen in a car intercepted a taxi carrying the policemen in El-Masseid in Al-Arish city and killed them along with the driver. The attackers were suspected Islamic State group militants.

A man was allegedly tortured in the Hurghada police station in the Red Sea governorate. The victim was arrested while driving a motorcycle for not having a drivers license. He was taken to the police station and beaten after he refused to be searched. He suffered tetraplegia and fractures to the spinal cord.

column16: AFP; Egypt Independent; Aswat Masriya (Egypt); AP
column17: A car bomb exploded in the Cairo suburb of Tagammu Khamis (Fifth Settlement) after Egypts deputy prosecutor general drove by on 29 September, wounding a passerby. A recently-emerged militant group called the Hasm Movement claimed responsibility for the assassination attempt.
Dozens of civilians in western Luxor staged a demonstration on Friday protesting the alleged torture of a man in the Hurghada police station last week.
In Rafah, security forces building a new checkpoint on the towns outskirts killed five militants who attacked the site to disrupt the construction.
Dozens of lawyers gathered on Saturday in a demonstration in front of Egypts High Court in protest against the recently-passed value-added tax (VAT) law.

Suspected Islamic State militants ambushed a taxi in which off-duty policemen were traveling back to their units on 1 October, killing five of them before fleeing. The incident took place just south of the coastal Sinai city of el-Arish.

Peaceful protests were staged by parents of government school students, particularly in Giza, outside the Ministry of Education building. The parents objected to an increase in the age requirement for Empirical Schools, a change that has removed the kindergarten level from such schools.

Suspected IS militants on 1 October kidnapped four clerics belonging to the Sufi sect of Islam from their homes in the village of Nagaa Shabanah on the Egyptian-Israeli border south of Rafah. The four, according to officials, had repeatedly spoken out in public against the killing by IS militants of local civilians suspected of links to security forces.
The severed head of a man kidnapped by the Islamic State militant group (ISIS) in Egypt was found in the street in the Hurriyah neighborhood of Rafah city.

A roadside bomb planted by suspected IS militants hit a police armored personnel carrier just outside the town of Rafah in northern Sinai, wounding nine policemen inside. One of the nine later died of his wounds in hospital.
Four workers from the state electricity company were killed when their car hit a roadside bomb at the coastal city of el-Arish. The bomb was planted by suspected Islamic State militants.

Police forces on 2 October allegedly stormed El-Basarta village in Damietta governorate, targeting houses affiliated to the Muslim Brotherhood. They then set houses on fire that were associated with former detainees.

A military funeral was held Sunday [2 October] in Al-Beheira governorate [northwest of Cairo] for three policemen, who were killed in an attack in Sinai. The mourners chanted slogans against ""terrorism"" and called for continuing war against ""militants"".

A senior figure in the Muslim Brotherhoods armed wing was killed along with his bodyguard during an exchange of fire with security forces in the Basateen area of Cairo. The Freedom and Justice Party accused security forces of committing a crime as the men were reportedly arrested prior to their killing, which amounts to ""extrajudicial execution.""

Four Copts, among them a child, were kidnapped on 3 October in the town of Manfalout in Assiut, some 350km south of Cairo. The kidnappers demanded a ransom of EGP500,000 or else they would kill the Copts.
Arrests: Ultras White Knights, fan-group of the Zamalek club, announced on Thursday that 48 of its members were arrested at the Alexandria train station.
Two children were shot and injured by an unknown gunman in Sheikh Zuweid.

Five police conscripts were allegedly killed on 7 October in an explosion caused by an improvised explosive device (IED) that targeted their armoured vehicle inside Al-Arish city in North Sinai governorate, according to IS-affiliated media outlet Ammaq.

Looting: Several members of the IS-affiliated group ""Sinai Province"" were reportedly responsible for the storming of a medical facility in the Sheikh Zewaid village of Al-Khewitar. There they seized two trucks affiliated to the facility. The militants used weapons to storm the medical facility and seized the two trucks for the sake of using them in further attacks against army and police checkpoints in different areas of North Sinai.
A Bedouin woman was injured on 8 October when anonymous militants opened fire at her while she was walking in Al-Hamayda village in Sheikh Zuweid.
A resident from Al-Sakadra village in Sheikh Zuweid, was injured by heavy shooting from anonymous militants on 8 October.

Residents of the village of Baarat, to the west of Luxor, held protests on 8 October against the alleged torture of a young man at Hurghada police station. The protesters demanded an investigation into the incident, which they said left the victim paralyzed, calling for the policemen involved to be brought to justice.

The Hasam Movement militant group claimed responsibility on 8 October for the killing of a policeman. Gunmen shot a policeman working with the Homeland Security agency, eight times outside his home in el Rahmaniya in the northern Beheira province.
Defusal: Two improvised explosive devices (IED) were safely detonated in Al-Arish city.

Four men were kidnapped from a cafe in Al-Massaeid suburb of Al-Arish city when anonymous militants drove up in a vehicle and took them hostage. The militants released the four men after nearly 10 hours; they had been violently assaulted during that time.

Heliopolis Sporting Club organised a peaceful protest against the accidents caused by lorries. Hundreds of people die every year in accidents. Participants called for the enactment of decisive laws that order lorry drivers to only drive at certain hours and at a certain speed.

A resident from Al-Arish was kidnapped, along with his wife from their house by anonymous militants. The married couple were taken under duress to an unknown place. The militants suspected them to be ""army operators"".

Following the death of a prisoner in Tanta, dozens of his relatives gathered at the Tanta public mortuary protesting the incident. Riot police surrounded the hospital to prevent the family members from clashing with officials.

A prisoner was found dead in Tanta police station. The prisoners family accuses police personnel of torturing him to death. He was arrested four days before his death on charges of theft. The family says that he refused to confess to stealing a mobile phone and was subsequently tortured.

Islamist militants killed 12 members of Egypts military in North Sinai province and wounded six more in an attack on a checkpoint. Islamic State claimed responsibility for the incident, which took place 40 km from the town of Bir al-Abd. 15 militants were killed in return.

The Egyptian military launched several airstrikes targeting militants in North Sinai in retaliation for an attack on Friday that killed 12 army personnel. A large number of militants were killed. The army statement on the airstrikes had no information about the number of militants killed. Al Bawaba News reported that the three-hour series of airstrikes are the largest, most wide-reaching counter-attack executed by the army in North Sinai since the beginning of the states war against ""terrorism"". The outlet reported that 140 militants were killed, Xinhua reported that at least 100 were killed.
Six men who Egyptian police reported were killed in clashes with militants on 13 January 2017 were reported to have been held in police custody since October 2016.
An officer was gunned down by a sniper in Al-Muqataa town in Sheikh Zuweid on 16 October.
Dozens of preachers from the Religious Endowments Ministry staged a protest on Sunday in front of the Egyptian parliament, demanding that their economic status be improved.

A conscript died following the explosion of an improvised explosive device that targeted a security armored vehicle while it was combing militant dens at Al-Gora town in southern Sheikh Zuweid city. Eight military conscripts were also wounded in separate blasts in the Sheikh Zuweyid city on 16 October.

A number of Ethiopians, including people from the Oromo and Amhara ethnic groups, gathered in front of the United Nations Higher Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) office in Cairo on Sunday to protest against the Ethiopian governments violations against opposition groups in their homeland. Another protest was being led by Sudanese nationals who were calling for UNHCR protection and recognition.
An officer and four conscripts died as an armed attack targeted their armored vehicle in Abu Tawila town of Sheikh Zuweid city.

column7: Military Forces of Egypt (2014-) Special Forces
column17: The Egyptian Air Forces raided 16 posts used by Islamist groups in Sinai on Sunday [16 October]. Artillery also bombed a number of other targets in parallel. Land and special troops took part in the crack down. 18 militants killed. 3 soldiers killed.
An Islamist militant sentenced to death was killed in a fire exchange with police forces tasked to arrest him in Gizas district of Kerdasa.
At least 19 militants and one soldier were killed on 17 October during a massive security campaign on militant hideouts the North Sinai province.

Hundreds of Egyptians protested in the coastal city of Port Said on 18 October against the rise in price of apartments provided under a low-income housing programme. An estimated 15-19 protesters were arrested after riot police dispersed a demonstration that broke out in the neighbourhood of Al-Sharq. Dozens of protesters blocked the roads.

A police officer and a conscript were killed, and four other police personnel injured, when their armoured vehicle was targeted in a mortar attack in Al-Tarbyeen, Sheikh Zuweid. The perpetrators are believed to be members of the Islamic State (IS)-affiliated group Sinai Province.""

Disgruntled owners and residents demonstrated in front of the the New Urban Communities Authority (NUCA) office in Sheikh Zayed, 6th of October City on Tuesday. The main proponent of their demands is for much-needed services for the area.
A housewife was forcibly disappeared by police forces in Menoufiya governorate after allegedly calling for protests on 11 November.
A conscript opened fire at a police officer during a quarrel in Garden City, killing the officer and injuring another, in Central Cairo.
Six Islamist militants were killed and seven hideouts were destroyed by the Egyptian army in Sinai on 18 October. Two servicemen were killed in the operation.
Two policemen were killed and one was injured in an explosion in North Sinai. Unidentified assailants planted a roadside bomb in the area of a police station in the town of Arish.
Minor protests organised by the pro-Morsi Anti Coup Alliance (ACA) chanted against the arrest of a housewife in Menoufiya governorate.

column9: Police Forces of Egypt (2014-) Prison Guards
column17: Six inmates fled the Ismailia Future Prison, rioting as they tried to escape and engaging in an exchange of fire with the police. A civilian and the head of the Abu Souir Investigation Bureau in Ismailia were killed in a jailbreak. Sources said that three of the fleeing prisoners are affiliated with the Sinai Province group. Three police officers and 13 other police conscripts and personnel against the backdrop of the jail break.
A political activist was stopped, beaten and arrested by a police officer at Talaat Harb Street near Tahrir Square on 21 October.
As many as 21 Islamist militants were killed and 16 explosive charges were defused during the ongoing military operations in North Sinai on Friday [21 October].

A senior Egyptian army officer was shot dead outside his home in the Obour City suburb of Cairo on 22 October. A group called Liwa al-Thawra claimed the attack. The officers driver was also killed in the incident, and a guard was injured.

Security Measures: Plain-clothes security forces raided the headquarters of Al-Tareeq news website in downtown Cairo on Sunday over the course of two hours and seized the reporters mobile phones and national ID cards, according to local media reports.

Around 240 workers from the Tanta Linen Factory staged a protest in front of the Egyptian Trade Union Federation (EFTU) demanding the governments intervention to rehire them in the factory after they were forced into early retirement. The demonstration took place in front of the EFTU headquarters in downtown Cairo. They were not prevented from protesting or harassed by police officers.

An explosive device targeting police forces detonated along a main road in Ain Shams, Cairo on 28 October, killing at least one civilian passerby and injuring another. No police injuries. There was no immediate claim of responsibility.

Dozens of residents cut the coastal road in Ras Gharib leading to Cairo, chanting slogans against the prime minister, complaining about water and electricity cuts resulting from the floods. Angry residents protested what they see as a slow response to flooding in the area.

column6: Military Forces of Egypt (2014-) Special Forces
column17: An explosion that struck an armoured vehicle on El-Gowra road in the North Sinai city of Sheikh Zuweid on 29 October killed an army lieutenant colonel from Al-Saaqa special forces along with two conscripts.
In two separate shooting incidents, two soldiers were wounded after militants opened fire on their checkpoints in Rafah.
A sniper fire killed one officer and injured a second in a checkpoint in a district called Beir Lahfan, south of el-Arish.
In El-Arish, three policemen and three civilians were wounded when a suicide bomber detonated a car bomb near a security convoy. The attack was claimed by State of Sinai militants.

Four Egyptian soldiers were killed during operations around El-Arish in northern Sinai province, close to the border with the Gaza Strip. Six Islamist militants were also killed. Twelve roadside bombs ready to detonate against security forces on highways were discharged.
The El-Zagdan checkpoint at Bir el-Abd in Sinai on 31 October was attacked by militants using snipers, leaving one soldier dead.

A police conscript was killed on Tuesday in El-Kontla, central Sinai when an improvised explosive device (IED) detonated in the vicinity of an armoured police vehicle. The explosion left a police officer and another conscript injured.

A video showed military forces and militia members executing a number of blindfolded prisoners, among which two brothers aged 16 and 19 years old, abducted in Rafah since July 2016. Soldiers also placed a weapon next to their body. Executions reportedly occurred on November 2 according to Sinai for Human Rights. In December, the army released photos of prisoners' bodies, along with weapons next to the corpses and claimed soldiers killed ""armed terrorists elements"" during a raid. (location unknown, coded as Al Arish geoprecision 3. Number of fatalities unclear, one source mentions 8 killed)

Between 1-3 ""suspects"" were killed and four officers reportedly injured during a police raid as clashes took place in Al-Harameen Street in Al-Salam city. ""The suspects belong to an armed wing of the Muslim Brotherhood. The raid was conducted following approval by the High State Security Prosecution.

A car bomb exploded on 4 November in the Nasr City area, causing no injuries. The explosion targeted judge Ahmed Abou Al-Fotouh who ruled in the Ittihadiya palace case whose defendants included former president Mohamed Morsi and other Muslim Brotherhood leaders. The Hasam Movement said it was behind the failed assassination attempt.

Gunmen killed a top Egyptian army officer outside his home in Al-Arish after weekly prayers on 4 November in the northern Sinai. The Islamic State (IS)-affiliated group ""Sinai Province"" claimed responsibility.

On 20 April, pro-Muslim Brotherhood satellite TV channel Mekameleen leaked a three-minute video showing part of a raid by the Egyptian army during which men in military outfit shot dead at least two young men and as many as eight, one of them blind-folded, at point blank range. Human Rights Watch said the men in the video belonged to a militia that helps the army against IS. The group said members of Egyptian military intelligence are shown directing executions before placing rifles next to bodies to depict the dead as militants killed in a raid. The group cited a network official as saying the killings took place in October or November in a village called al-Tuma, south of Sheikh Zuweid in northern Sinai Peninsula. Date uncertain but coded to an official media releases published by the Egyptian armed forces on November 5.
